description: Adobe Premiere Pro Creative Cloud is used by video professionals and enthusiasts to edit and export their projects.  It is timeline-based and can sync multiple camera tracks while using advanced built-in styles and templates to add title sequences and lighting/camera effects. This course covers exam objectives for the Adobe Certified Associate (ACA) certification.
name: Premiere Pro CC
subtitle: Video Editing Application

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James introduce you to Adobe's Premiere Pro initial user interface. They walk you through opening Premiere for the first time and creating a new project. They also show you the general project settings and user control preferences. Finally they explore the audio settings, media types and syncing with the Adobe Creative Cloud.
episodes.title: Opening and Initial Settings

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James take a look at Premiere's windows or Monitors. They show you how to move or resize the Monitors to personalize the interface layout. Next they demonstrate editing the Monitors and how to jump in and out of fullscreen with a keyboard shortcut. Finally they show you how to create your own custom keyboard shortcuts.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James discuss the processes of Importing and Ingesting. They show Ingesting single and multiple files and Importing folders of media. They also discuss using the importance of using Premiere's Media Browser to bring in media instead of Finder or some other file explorer.

00:18:10.670 --> 00:18:13.249
So if I say Preview Area,

that just took away a ton

If you need screen real estate,

What that means is if

So that is now the thumbnail down here,
okay?

00:19:14.330 --> 00:19:15.738
So I can reset that.

Especially people who use clap slates,
where they've got

00:19:18.850 --> 00:19:22.570

You really wanna say,
okay, I like the icons, but

00:19:28.210 --> 00:19:32.990
The cool thing about this is,

>> Don't think of it at as

>> Last thing,

Well I'll say no, no, no.

00:20:26.307 --> 00:20:29.670

I can add another parameter if I want, but

365
00:20:35.650 --> 00:20:42.390
Boom and now in this search folder,

00:20:42.390 --> 00:20:44.720
That's all, that's everything.

It did not move it out of the 5D folder.

00:20:49.920 --> 00:20:51.840
It didn't move it out of the 5D folder.

It just said, okay, I searched for

If I delete this folder,

But this is an awesome way, instead of

00:21:04.970 --> 00:21:08.410
I'll just say no, I'm just gonna create

I can have a bunch I can

And it helps me get through here really

00:21:58.060 --> 00:22:05.270

00:22:05.270 --> 00:22:07.140

These actually ingested and

00:22:11.030 --> 00:22:17.480
The ones that I simply imported, they're

00:22:17.480 --> 00:22:22.090
So you can feel safe that you know the

It's built right into Premiere.

Adobe has heard our cries and

00:22:54.750 --> 00:22:55.588

And now we know how to get some

00:23:01.640 --> 00:23:03.274

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James explain how to keep your Project Window organized for ease of use. This will include renaming media folders, renaming clips, using columns, and creating custom columns. They also start modifying original source files using the Premiere Media Browser.
episodes.title: Organizing Your Project Window

Get away from me.

Okay, now it's like ascending,

Let say I'm say I just don't want to deal

It's like, wait a minute,
what's happening it's gone, no.

Understood, it's not up in here,

So, there's all kinds of
different things that you can do,

But when I control click on things,

and one of them being to hide something,
to view the hidden,

00:04:34.230 --> 00:04:36.200
I won't want to hide that anymore.

00:04:36.200 --> 00:04:37.460
Okay.

00:04:37.460 --> 00:04:40.040
Nice.
So there are certain things I can do to

00:04:40.040 --> 00:04:40.980
all of this.

I can make custom columns.

00:04:43.710 --> 00:04:46.850
If you want a custom column,

I can control click.

Well, let's take on the first one,

If you're regular Photoshop user, you

I don't do that, so

But notice I have this thing called

When I look in there,

So all these other things,

Click okay, we zoom back out here,

There's a bug, and it sorts it for me, so

Some people love this,
some people not to into it.

If you're not into it, that's why

We did beforehand.

The reason I did a search

That is available in this window,

Notice there's a search or a find in this

>> Right, it's just like find them all,

00:08:42.868 --> 00:08:44.830
So, you know, there's so

many different ways that you can search

00:08:50.700 --> 00:08:52.000
It is great.

165
00:08:52.000 --> 00:08:54.690
And again-
>> Obviously very unprofessional software,

and no one will ever use this.

00:08:55.810 --> 00:08:56.720

I mean,

00:08:58.591 --> 00:09:00.360

00:09:00.360 --> 00:09:02.740
And one of the reasons why you might

00:09:02.740 --> 00:09:03.300
>> Yeah.
>> And

you do the find because you've got

00:09:05.940 --> 00:09:08.770
I just want to find this, and

00:09:08.770 --> 00:09:13.260
it goes to a different one you're like,

00:09:13.260 --> 00:09:16.330
Or you can also, like I said,

00:09:16.330 --> 00:09:20.570
If you're doing a lot of work over time,

00:09:20.570 --> 00:09:25.770
it's great to use columns, because the

00:09:25.770 --> 00:09:30.960
And then you will notice

I could have done a couple of

00:09:35.180 --> 00:09:36.420
Within those fields.

And that would make me happy to do that.

00:09:39.400 --> 00:09:39.930
Okay?

00:09:39.930 --> 00:09:43.830
Especially if I wanted to find everything,

00:09:43.830 --> 00:09:49.337
which is really evil, but

00:09:49.337 --> 00:09:54.010
to go to the cannon here and zoom in.

00:09:54.010 --> 00:09:56.310
And you will notice this little

00:09:56.310 --> 00:10:00.480
which is terrible, is shot at 23.976.

00:10:00.480 --> 00:10:05.700
The other stuff that I

00:10:05.700 --> 00:10:10.710
I shot that at 60 frames per second,
just so I would have mixed media.

00:10:10.710 --> 00:10:12.770
This one was shot at 30.

00:10:12.770 --> 00:10:15.060
And then this stuff was shot at 60.

00:10:15.060 --> 00:10:19.360
So, now what I'm going to have to

00:10:20.720 --> 00:10:25.140
boy, I've got mixed media,

00:10:25.140 --> 00:10:26.510
That is crazy.

00:10:26.510 --> 00:10:31.540
The other thing we may
want to do with this

00:10:31.540 --> 00:10:37.400
is sometimes I need to organize
something about the clip itself.

197
00:10:37.400 --> 00:10:43.210
Let me come down to this thing right here,

00:10:43.210 --> 00:10:46.000
okay, this is the movie,
this is me talking.

00:10:46.000 --> 00:10:48.170
This is me doing a lot of talking.

200
00:10:48.170 --> 00:10:50.008
All right, we're going to
cut up this interview later.

00:10:50.008 --> 00:10:53.280
If I ctrl+click it,
this is where I get the clips menu.

00:10:55.460 --> 00:11:00.640
What I am able to do with this is
I can look at the properties for

00:11:00.640 --> 00:11:02.850
this in a separate menu.

00:11:02.850 --> 00:11:10.680
I am able to actually reveal this In the

00:11:10.680 --> 00:11:16.350
Occasionally, we may want to modify things

00:11:16.350 --> 00:11:20.110
One of them generally
being audio channels.

207
00:11:20.110 --> 00:11:20.780
Okay?

208
00:11:20.780 --> 00:11:26.730
So, we are able to do that,
I don’t have to do this one by one,

209
00:11:26.730 --> 00:11:30.580
I can do this to multiple
files at the same time.

00:11:30.580 --> 00:11:33.740
You may run into the fact where sometimes,
what happens is,

00:11:33.740 --> 00:11:36.140
I’m just going to do
this is as an example.

212
00:11:36.140 --> 00:11:39.210
What happens is you brought
in some footage, and

00:11:39.210 --> 00:11:42.030
you have noticed the left
channel has audio in it.

214
00:11:42.030 --> 00:11:46.660
The right channel is either dead or
too low, or making a lovely hiss.

215
00:11:48.040 --> 00:11:50.654
And what you want to do is you want
to get started [INAUDIBLE] and

216
00:11:50.654 --> 00:11:52.050
then you get into the timeline.

217
00:11:52.050 --> 00:11:58.350
And it's like,
now I have to handle all of that now?

218
00:11:58.350 --> 00:12:01.170
When all I want to do is cut and
make a story.

219
00:12:01.170 --> 00:12:05.580
What I could do at the source level as
part of, or that's the project level.

220
00:12:05.580 --> 00:12:08.400
As part of that beginning organization
is to say, you know what?

221
00:12:09.590 --> 00:12:15.020
The right channel on this clip
make it the left channel.

222
00:12:15.020 --> 00:12:17.840
So now the left channel is in left and
right, and

223
00:12:17.840 --> 00:12:21.630
the audio is clear in both channels, and

224
00:12:21.630 --> 00:12:25.860
I've done this at the project level,
and I could do that to multiple files.

225
00:12:25.860 --> 00:12:31.590
And that's really what I want to do
as part of this project organization.

226
00:12:31.590 --> 00:12:33.890
>> Save yourself a little bit
of administrative headache.

227
00:12:33.890 --> 00:12:37.400
>> Save a lot of time, not only that,
we're going to, once we really,

228
00:12:37.400 --> 00:12:45.250
really get into a facts,
I can save what I just did as a preset.

229
00:12:46.250 --> 00:12:54.620
And I could say I could come down here and
I can say GOODLEFT boom.

230
00:12:54.620 --> 00:12:59.460
So now the next time this happens, all I
have to do is go to my good left preset

231
00:12:59.460 --> 00:13:03.890
and it's done, and I'm handling
all of this in the project window.

232
00:13:03.890 --> 00:13:06.720
I'm not trying to, and I see so many
people trying to do this, and I feel so

00:13:06.720 --> 00:13:10.020
bad for them, because they're like okay,
now I have everything in a timeline.

234
00:13:10.020 --> 00:13:12.730
And now I have to correct it,
I have to correct everything,

235
00:13:12.730 --> 00:13:15.740
when it could have been
handled in the project window.

236
00:13:15.740 --> 00:13:18.030
Same thing with this guy,
interpret footage.

237
00:13:19.140 --> 00:13:23.450
This is one of my absolute
favorite things to work with

00:13:23.450 --> 00:13:27.350
because right now it's saying,
this is 23.976.

239
00:13:27.350 --> 00:13:28.050
Okay, or 24p.

00:13:28.050 --> 00:13:29.680
Everybody knows there's 24p.

241
00:13:31.340 --> 00:13:33.120
Let's say I create.

00:13:33.120 --> 00:13:35.160
And this will, we're going to do so later.

00:13:35.160 --> 00:13:39.980
I created 24 frame,
then I created 24 frame sequence, but

244
00:13:39.980 --> 00:13:42.500
I've got some 60 frame per second footage.

00:13:44.560 --> 00:13:46.610
If I put those two together in a sequence,
that's 24,

00:13:46.610 --> 00:13:48.679
the 60 is going to look just fine.

247
00:13:49.768 --> 00:13:52.940
It's going to look just fine, but let's
say I wanted to run super slow motion.

248
00:13:54.340 --> 00:13:57.220
What I could have done is said, hey,

00:13:58.840 --> 00:14:03.680
at the source level assume that that's
24 frames or in this case, 23.976.

250
00:14:03.680 --> 00:14:07.160
And then it puts it

251
00:14:07.160 --> 00:14:11.888
So I'm able to change these things

252
00:14:11.888 --> 00:14:19.830
Also, sometimes maybe you ended up and
you got something that was,

00:14:19.830 --> 00:14:23.780

00:14:23.780 --> 00:14:27.700
It's like, at this level, I can say,

256
00:14:33.020 --> 00:14:36.460
I can handle all of these

The other two has maybe got a graphic,
and it has an alpha

00:14:41.670 --> 00:14:44.660
channel on it which is a transparency,
is like I don't want an alpha channel,

259
00:14:44.660 --> 00:14:48.090
unless you take it off,
ignore it, invert it.

260
00:14:48.090 --> 00:14:50.800
Okay?
Sometimes people get the wrong, it's like,

261
00:14:50.800 --> 00:14:52.230
wait, it's supposed to be black as white,
wait,

262
00:14:52.230 --> 00:14:53.580
is the alpha channel black,
is the alpha channel white?

263
00:14:53.580 --> 00:14:56.100
You brought it in wrong, I can invert it.

264
00:14:56.100 --> 00:15:00.850
And I can do all of these at the project
level, it doesn't affect media.

265
00:15:00.850 --> 00:15:04.140
It just manages the metadata on that.

266
00:15:04.140 --> 00:15:09.570
So instead of, I'm going to do all these

00:15:09.570 --> 00:15:14.560
It's like I have the ability to do

00:15:14.560 --> 00:15:19.540

00:15:19.540 --> 00:15:20.320
blah, blah, blah, blah, blah.

270
00:15:20.320 --> 00:15:20.840
>> It's cool.

00:15:20.840 --> 00:15:23.400
It really seems like
an organizational filter.

00:15:23.400 --> 00:15:25.840
So I say, well here's my raw data or

273
00:15:25.840 --> 00:15:26.480

>> But
just kind of run it through here and

00:15:27.930 --> 00:15:30.160
make it look like this when

00:15:30.160 --> 00:15:31.350
>> Right, and it's like-

00:15:31.350 --> 00:15:31.960

00:15:31.960 --> 00:15:33.505
>> Yeah.
And once I get cutting, and

00:15:33.505 --> 00:15:36.420

I don't want to have to go back and

00:15:36.420 --> 00:15:38.900

now I got to fix that.

281
00:15:38.900 --> 00:15:43.700
It's like I'm making something,
I want to make it.

282
00:15:43.700 --> 00:15:45.960
It's kind of like baking.

283
00:15:45.960 --> 00:15:47.455
It confounds me.

284
00:15:47.455 --> 00:15:48.500
>> [LAUGH]
>> And then you know,

00:15:48.500 --> 00:15:52.410
usually when I forgot to put some

00:15:52.410 --> 00:15:56.370
and then it's like I'm halfway, and this

00:15:56.370 --> 00:15:58.180
it's like when I should

00:15:58.180 --> 00:16:01.060
And that's what I'm doing right here,

289
00:16:01.060 --> 00:16:05.190
But it really,
really helps you if you get in there and

290
00:16:05.190 --> 00:16:10.090

291
00:16:10.090 --> 00:16:12.180
So that's really what this

00:16:12.180 --> 00:16:16.090
Just a quick thing of look,

00:16:16.090 --> 00:16:19.380
It doesn't have to be like

00:16:19.380 --> 00:16:20.880
It can be as simple as you want it to be.

295
00:16:20.880 --> 00:16:22.410
It can be as elaborate as you want to be.

00:16:22.410 --> 00:16:26.360
That's the great thing that Adobe does,

00:16:26.360 --> 00:16:27.680
How simple do you want it to be?

00:16:27.680 --> 00:16:29.000
Here are all the options.

00:16:29.000 --> 00:16:30.120

300
00:16:30.120 --> 00:16:33.550
Obviously Adobe's not

00:16:33.550 --> 00:16:37.680
They're making it as simple as possible,

302
00:16:37.680 --> 00:16:41.530
as little or as much as you need, for

303
00:16:41.530 --> 00:16:42.150
James?
>> Right.

00:16:42.150 --> 00:16:44.190

>> So that we can use this.

00:16:45.600 --> 00:16:50.670
Do a better job at making things

00:16:50.670 --> 00:16:52.097
I know you wanted it so bad.

00:17:01.210 --> 00:17:04.409

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James begin taking a closer look into the Source Monitor and basic editing. They start by creating a keyboard shortcut to cycle through the Monitors/Windows quickly, then they do some basic audio and video editing, showing you how to sync separate audio and video clips to create a segment for a Sequence in the Timeline Monitor.
episodes.title: Source Window and Basic Editing

WEBVTT

This is my favorite thing

cuz they don't know some of the cool

00:00:49.230 --> 00:00:53.190
I just made the project window bigger

usually what people do,
let's say I've got some sync audio here.

What most people do is they just

If I go up here to Close All, now there's

if I had the source window I could just

And all I see is one but if I go up
here to the panel menu I can say,

okay now show me number four,
now show me number five, now show me this.

It doesn't react to this side in the same
way because you have this option.

497
00:27:04.440 --> 00:27:05.628
>> Important safety tip, right?

498
00:27:05.628 --> 00:27:06.967
>> Important safety tip, you know.

499
00:27:06.967 --> 00:27:08.367
>> Gotta make sure you're using
the right controls there.

500
00:27:08.367 --> 00:27:10.553
>> Yeah,
just make sure the right controls.

And that's because, most times when

the timeline,
they don't really care about this.

503
00:27:15.510 --> 00:27:19.420
I don't like this, or I don't really use
it, so I'm just gonna do it this way.

504
00:27:19.420 --> 00:27:21.460
Which is absolutely fine,
you pick what you wanna do.

505
00:27:22.630 --> 00:27:26.315
Lastly, just wanna take a look at a couple
of items in here that you'll probably be

506
00:27:26.315 --> 00:27:26.890
interested in.

507
00:27:26.890 --> 00:27:31.760
Notice, I have,
it shows me all kinds of great symbols.

508
00:27:31.760 --> 00:27:36.380
I can go to the in point, I can go to
the out point, and it shows me here.

509
00:27:36.380 --> 00:27:41.380
With that, I have the ability to, wow,
I wonder if I can go straight to that

510
00:27:41.380 --> 00:27:46.610
marker without click, cuz kinda
finding it's not really a happy thing.

511
00:27:46.610 --> 00:27:49.825
If I hit this plus sign,

00:27:49.825 --> 00:27:51.179
I wonder if there's a go to?

00:27:51.179 --> 00:27:52.513
There is!

514
00:27:52.513 --> 00:27:54.210
There are these go to markers.

00:27:54.210 --> 00:27:58.480
And what I could say is I really

00:27:58.480 --> 00:28:01.920
And can I put that one there?

517
00:28:01.920 --> 00:28:06.345
And then say OK, and
now I can go straight to the marker?

518
00:28:06.345 --> 00:28:09.530
Yes, and I have that symbol as well.

519
00:28:09.530 --> 00:28:13.357
>> Okay, so I thought I was not

520
00:28:13.357 --> 00:28:15.639
Unfortunately, you proved me wrong.

00:28:15.639 --> 00:28:16.415
>> That's all I got for you.

522
00:28:16.415 --> 00:28:17.640
>> That was pretty good,
that was pretty good.

523
00:28:17.640 --> 00:28:18.140
I like that.

524
00:28:18.140 --> 00:28:21.793
>> Yeah, so this is just some basic edits,

00:28:21.793 --> 00:28:25.420
In the next one, we're gonna try

526
00:28:25.420 --> 00:28:25.980
So, yeah.

527
00:28:25.980 --> 00:28:27.512
>> Well very cool, I actually-
>> Let's get to it!

528
00:28:27.512 --> 00:28:28.048
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

529
00:28:28.048 --> 00:28:31.484
I actually feel like I could

00:28:31.484 --> 00:28:33.419

531
00:28:33.419 --> 00:28:34.245
>> Good.

532
00:28:34.245 --> 00:28:36.680

But our clock has dwindled

But there's another one coming up,

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James discuss and demonstrate using the Timeline and Program Monitors/Windows. They also explain the use of In and Out points, duplicate shot markers, and lots of keyboard shortcuts.
episodes.title: Timeline and Program Monitor
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.004 --> 00:00:10.004
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.975 --> 00:00:13.520
All Right, greetings, everyone.

3
00:00:13.520 --> 00:00:16.770
Welcome to another exciting
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:16.770 --> 00:00:17.910
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

5
00:00:17.910 --> 00:00:21.120
In today's episode,
we move forward on more of our series.

6

On Premiere Pro, and
gracing our studio with his presence yet

Mr. James Biddle.

James, sir, so glad to have you.

All right, from what I can see.

11

>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, so here's the deal.

12

We're gonna move on quickly to

And you're gonna see some similarities

the cool thing is,
once you get into the program in time, so

15
00:00:49.730 --> 00:00:53.700
many more new things that you can
control and make settings for.

16
00:00:53.700 --> 00:00:58.290
So I'm going to go back real

17
00:00:58.290 --> 00:00:59.400
I want you to notice something.

00:00:59.400 --> 00:01:03.780
Last time I added an extra
couple of buttons there, okay?

19
00:01:03.780 --> 00:01:07.350
I added the go to previous marker,

00:01:07.350 --> 00:01:09.900
If I tighten up this window a little bit,

go to previous marker, are not seeing,

24
00:01:21.570 --> 00:01:24.350
Okay?
So if you squeeze up your Windows

you will get some of those down here, with

If you're one of those really
interesting people that says,

00:01:34.530 --> 00:01:38.680
hey I don't need transport controls,

00:01:38.680 --> 00:01:42.655
Guess what,
the wrench deals a lot with settings.

So if I go to Settings I can say,

Boom, even more real estate for you,

just one of those options, I'm gonna
put them back on so I feel safe again.

34

All right, if I come back

00:02:03.300 --> 00:02:06.870
notice they move simultaneously.

00:02:06.870 --> 00:02:11.680
Okay, they move simultaneously,
because this is where you build

00:02:11.680 --> 00:02:15.330
in the timeline that everybody's

00:02:15.330 --> 00:02:18.740
this is what they're going

When the edits actually happen,

Couple things up in this window that

That's the playhead position.

I can also type in values to say,

00:02:41.590 --> 00:02:42.600
it will take me right there.

00:02:42.600 --> 00:02:44.680
So I could do this let's see, five.

48
00:02:44.680 --> 00:02:50.680
Boom, and it takes me to five seconds,

49
00:02:50.680 --> 00:02:56.000
So if I had just done five, that is five
frames, if I do five, come here you.

50
00:02:56.000 --> 00:03:00.350
Let's say I wanna go to exactly

00:03:00.350 --> 00:03:03.730
five seconds, boom and

Because, yes, I can put ins and

outs points in the timeline to do

What I was doing before was in

I want this much distance,

00:03:18.718 --> 00:03:24.520
In a timeline I can say hey,

So, that's why we have the ability

Again, I have another plus on this one,

There is a lot that I can do

Fit to window is going to come into

I could because this is

I can just choose here, and say, actually

00:04:35.710 --> 00:04:40.450
Now, the interesting part is,

00:04:40.450 --> 00:04:41.830
you just kicked it to a quarter and

it still looks okay play,
it's like now it looks kind of pooey.

00:04:47.890 --> 00:04:48.810
Now it looks okay.

00:04:48.810 --> 00:04:50.680
Why is that the case?

Because if I go back to the wrench,

not only do I have a playback resolution,

So when it pauses,

I could say, okay,
I find that mildly disturbing and

But, I prefer to be like,

00:05:15.320 --> 00:05:19.350
it pauses at full because I may

88
00:05:19.350 --> 00:05:24.020
Or, because I have that same

00:05:29.490 --> 00:05:30.960
Okay, I can pull export frames and

00:05:30.960 --> 00:05:33.640
I kinda want that full

00:05:35.270 --> 00:05:39.470
What can be done up here if

There are a lot of settings in

Now of course we have a panel menu,

I zoom back, if I turn it on, if you

Okay, After Effects uses a work area bar

Most of us who are editors are like,

So we will turn that off,

00:06:20.480 --> 00:06:23.420
Audio Waveforms Use Label Color,

If I turn them off.

00:06:26.900 --> 00:06:30.430
They're going to be same as the blue.

00:06:30.430 --> 00:06:35.240
And I don't necessarily like that,

Rectified audio wave forms

Most folks might be used to this.

Where's it's on both

Some people really prefer a rectified one,

00:06:48.040 --> 00:06:53.020
There are many different things

00:06:53.020 --> 00:06:54.610
I'm gonna go ahead and do rectified.

114
00:06:56.180 --> 00:07:00.368
Another thing that people like is I

Now you might be saying to yourself,

So here are some new hotkeys, okay.

Plus and minus.

00:07:16.130 --> 00:07:19.730
You can zoom in toward the play head is,

If I add a modifier to that.

If I add command, okay?

00:07:24.080 --> 00:07:29.310
What I'm doing is all the video

00:07:30.360 --> 00:07:34.950

00:07:34.950 --> 00:07:40.120
Which is, I want, video head,

00:07:41.760 --> 00:07:45.327
So that way I can have it that way,

00:07:45.327 --> 00:07:50.357
Continuous kind of freaks me out,

00:07:50.357 --> 00:07:55.232
I can do, all right,
the last thing that I like

00:08:00.530 --> 00:08:04.780
As in I may have a lot of sequences.

And I can just say,

00:08:10.990 --> 00:08:13.490
In the project boom and it is done that.

00:08:13.490 --> 00:08:15.400
Let me just zoom in real quick.

00:08:15.400 --> 00:08:16.580
It's actually highlighted.

00:08:16.580 --> 00:08:20.940
If it was buried in a bin some

00:08:20.940 --> 00:08:26.310
Okay, so once again in here I

00:08:26.310 --> 00:08:32.130
If I had the option modifier plus minus,

00:08:32.130 --> 00:08:33.940
We do the command modifier again.

139
00:08:33.940 --> 00:08:37.900
If I do shift plus boom,

140
00:08:37.900 --> 00:08:39.650

141
00:08:39.650 --> 00:08:41.930
So it jumps in and jumps out.

142
00:08:41.930 --> 00:08:45.100
If you wanna do them individually,
you can just grab the bar,

143
00:08:45.100 --> 00:08:48.410
just It's kinda like other
applications that do spread sheets.

144
00:08:48.410 --> 00:08:50.990
They'll do that and
you can do that exact same thing.

145
00:08:50.990 --> 00:08:54.340
>> A lot of cool options with
getting it just right cuz

146
00:08:54.340 --> 00:08:57.000
I'm assuming that's actually a big deal.

147
00:08:57.000 --> 00:08:59.810
It's not something simple that,
I can make it bigger or

00:08:59.810 --> 00:09:02.620
smaller, when you're doing

149
00:09:02.620 --> 00:09:04.530
Absolutely.
>> A really nice feature to have debating

00:09:04.530 --> 00:09:05.180
just right.

151
00:09:05.180 --> 00:09:08.410
>> Like they said, the last thing
you wanna do is go burying your head

152
00:09:08.410 --> 00:09:10.530
into the monitor when you can zoom in and

00:09:10.530 --> 00:09:12.400

see it much, much better.

00:09:12.400 --> 00:09:14.740
Especially if you're
working with waveforms or

00:09:14.740 --> 00:09:16.290
if you're working with key frames.

156
00:09:16.290 --> 00:09:19.110
Which, when we deal with
effects getting in there and

00:09:19.110 --> 00:09:22.050

158
00:09:22.050 --> 00:09:26.500
Okay, so coming back, if I go to the
wrench, it says timeline display settings.

159
00:09:26.500 --> 00:09:28.830
I can choose even though I said earlier,

160
00:09:28.830 --> 00:09:33.090
hey I like video, I can choose to
simply not see them whatsoever.

161
00:09:33.090 --> 00:09:34.860
I can not show the audio waveform.

162
00:09:36.320 --> 00:09:38.490
Clip markers I don't know why, but

163
00:09:38.490 --> 00:09:42.870
sometimes when you put a marker on a clip
like I did before and I synced the audio.

164
00:09:42.870 --> 00:09:46.890
Some people don't wanna see those markers
in the timeline, not exactly sure why.

165
00:09:47.910 --> 00:09:51.190
I'm going to activate duplicate
frame markers for now, so

166
00:09:51.190 --> 00:09:53.580
you can see something a little bit later.

167
00:09:53.580 --> 00:09:56.150
But these are a lot of visual choices.

168
00:09:56.150 --> 00:09:58.660
Okay, this annoys me,
I don't wanna see this right now.

169
00:09:58.660 --> 00:10:02.020
Or it's critical that I
see this at this moment.

170
00:10:02.020 --> 00:10:07.029
You can set those in that way, and that's
usually with the timeline display setting.

171
00:10:09.020 --> 00:10:12.920
Over here, blue,
once again playhead position.

172
00:10:12.920 --> 00:10:16.490
I can move or go to a specific

173
00:10:18.090 --> 00:10:23.930
We have two here that are very,
very, I would say people love these.

174
00:10:23.930 --> 00:10:30.810
Okay link so if this is on,
if this is blue every time I tap the video

175
00:10:30.810 --> 00:10:35.750
it will highlight the selected
audio okay a lot of people like

176
00:10:35.750 --> 00:10:39.610
this it's like whenever I hit the video I
want to be able to select that audio too.

177

realizing that this playhead,
as it looks down,

406
00:23:32.470 --> 00:23:35.310

407
00:23:35.310 --> 00:23:37.640
I kind of call it timeline gymnastics, and

408
00:23:37.640 --> 00:23:40.800
just kind of go through it,
get comfortable with it.

409
00:23:40.800 --> 00:23:45.690
And then when we go into the next set of
edits, when we start to do overwrites and

00:23:45.690 --> 00:23:48.610

things up and move them around,

00:23:48.610 --> 00:23:52.589

412
00:23:54.760 --> 00:23:56.230
That's really, really fun,

413
00:23:56.230 --> 00:24:00.860
when you understand how this right side
works, and how that plate head works.

414
00:24:00.860 --> 00:24:02.850
So I hope that was helpful.

415
00:24:02.850 --> 00:24:03.900
I wasn't running too fast.

416
00:24:03.900 --> 00:24:05.320
>> No, Jim, it was awesome actually.

417

It was very entertaining.

418
00:24:06.860 --> 00:24:07.780
>> Great, good, all right, all right.

419

I can go fast. [CROSSTALK] >> Yeah,
let me show you how quick [CROSSTALK].

>> No, that's fine, okay.

I think that it was your

>> It's all the host.

428
00:24:26.960 --> 00:24:27.580
It's all the host.

429
00:24:27.580 --> 00:24:28.230
>> Yes.

430
00:24:28.230 --> 00:24:29.140
>> It's all the host.

431

Without him, I don't.

432

433

>> All right Jim,

is there anything else we need

And then when we get into the advanced

Now when we go into the overwrites,

I'm ready.

I'm ready, I know why this did that.

>> Yeah, yeah.

I guess we're moving

>> Okay yeah it's

like
>> That's

Hopefully you'll be able to master

00:25:28.512 --> 00:25:29.961

00:25:29.961 --> 00:25:39.070

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James dive into performing Overwrite and Replace edits and the difference between the two. They also discuss and demonstrate doing a Matched Frame Replace.
episodes.title: Overwrite and Replace Edits
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

[MUSIC]

2

3

great episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:16.009 --> 00:00:17.250

5

I'm just, I'm just gonna stick

Then there's this comment that
a lot of people make about

when you get into an editing system,
it's just a hammer.

What I did was I created

I remember I had this

So, what I'll say is,

there's always a remedy, and

They always give you a warning.

So, the thing is, up here, and

00:07:11.950 --> 00:07:15.280
>> And, the reason why I'm shooting

I haven't seen my backyard in a about

You can.

Some people will say, I never do that.

Some people say, I always do that.

Depending on your situation, you may

So, all I have to do is click

>> It's assuming that what you're
pulling from the source is what you want

403
00:21:29.640 --> 00:21:30.450
>> Exactly, it's like-

404
00:21:30.450 --> 00:21:31.390
>> And forget what else you have.

405
00:21:31.390 --> 00:21:33.480
>> It's like oops,
I left something in the.

406
00:21:33.480 --> 00:21:34.450
I have done that before too.

407
00:21:34.450 --> 00:21:37.230
It's like man,
there's an out point in there, what?

408
00:21:37.230 --> 00:21:38.190
What happened?

409
00:21:38.190 --> 00:21:39.540
So yeah.

410
00:21:39.540 --> 00:21:42.760
You can also do ignore the source in
point, ignore the source out point,

411
00:21:42.760 --> 00:21:44.330
ignore the sequence in point.

412
00:21:44.330 --> 00:21:46.830
The other one is called change clip speed,
fit to fill.

413
00:21:46.830 --> 00:21:52.020
When we deal with speed, what it will do
is it will say okay make the clip faster.

414
00:21:52.020 --> 00:21:58.290
Make the clip slower by fitting it
into the range in the timeline.

415
00:21:58.290 --> 00:21:59.910
It doesn't work in the reverse.

416
00:21:59.910 --> 00:22:01.490
Okay?
The source would have to fit

417
00:22:01.490 --> 00:22:05.240
in the range of the timeline by
what you selected in the source.

418
00:22:05.240 --> 00:22:09.650
So, in this case, I'll say,
actually, yes, that was correct.

419
00:22:09.650 --> 00:22:13.915
Now, you can,
some people are like this upsets me.

420
00:22:14.975 --> 00:22:19.945
I just, it's always the fact that I
always blow the sequence out point,

421
00:22:19.945 --> 00:22:23.825
okay, I can look up the fit to fill and
do that as a command.

422
00:22:23.825 --> 00:22:26.890
I don't worry about the other stuff.

423
00:22:26.890 --> 00:22:30.590
It's like, all right, I can just choose to
say, always take this and take this away.

424
00:22:31.710 --> 00:22:33.400
Boom, there it is.

425
00:22:33.400 --> 00:22:36.390
Now it's funny, I'm gonna have two things.

426
00:22:36.390 --> 00:22:37.040
>> Cleaned out.

427
00:22:37.040 --> 00:22:38.000
So I'm doing this video.

428
00:22:38.000 --> 00:22:40.060
>> Whoops, sorry about that,
let's go back down here.

429
00:22:40.060 --> 00:22:41.780
Gotta watch what's highlighted.

430
00:22:41.780 --> 00:22:42.510
>> It's in blue.

431
00:22:42.510 --> 00:22:43.700
>> And get rid of the-
>> I know.

432
00:22:43.700 --> 00:22:46.520
>> You can see what it's like in the-
>> And delay, I'm talking on the top of

433
00:22:46.520 --> 00:22:48.860
myself which is really funny,
so I did not mean to do that.

434
00:22:48.860 --> 00:22:51.100
But it shows a demo of this whole thing,

435
00:22:51.100 --> 00:22:55.920
if you accidentally have four points
instead of three, what's gonna happen?

436
00:22:55.920 --> 00:22:59.740
Adobe is full aware of this because,
as an editor,

437
00:22:59.740 --> 00:23:02.830
I like that a lot because
occasionally I put something in here,

438
00:23:02.830 --> 00:23:05.120
I put something in there,
I've completely forgotten about it.

439
00:23:05.120 --> 00:23:09.810
And then I get this warning, it's like,
great, instead of me performing an edit

440
00:23:09.810 --> 00:23:14.290
and then going, wait a minute,
I don't understand what's happening.

441
00:23:14.290 --> 00:23:18.810
And I didn't realize, there may be
a situation when there's a point somewhere

442
00:23:18.810 --> 00:23:21.740
that you completely forgot about,
you accidentally hit a button.

443
00:23:21.740 --> 00:23:26.220
So this beautiful little
warning is just great.

444
00:23:26.220 --> 00:23:29.600
So those are overwrite and
replacement edits.

445
00:23:29.600 --> 00:23:33.320
Replacement being somewhat
of a form of overwrite.

446
00:23:33.320 --> 00:23:35.030
And this is fun to play with.

447
00:23:35.030 --> 00:23:37.170
It's one of those things like,
get in a timeline,

448
00:23:37.170 --> 00:23:41.660
experiment, see how it works,
have fun with it.

449
00:23:41.660 --> 00:23:45.680
So yeah, so you've added more tools to
your toolkit instead of just going,

450
00:23:45.680 --> 00:23:46.830
I'm always gonna use this.

451
00:23:46.830 --> 00:23:51.560
No, occasionally you wanna use something
else, and it can be really cool.

452
00:23:51.560 --> 00:23:54.980
>> Yeah, so you can really expand
your horizons because now we

453
00:23:54.980 --> 00:23:59.840
have the ability to say well yeah you know
I am gonna make it look a little more

454
00:23:59.840 --> 00:24:02.348
awesome than just to state,
okay here's a couple of me.

455
00:24:02.348 --> 00:24:03.680
It cut to this,

456
00:24:03.680 --> 00:24:07.960
it cut to that, now we've got a nice
transition into another piece of media.

457
00:24:07.960 --> 00:24:12.730
It all starts to come together, it looks
like a better way to tell stories,

458
00:24:12.730 --> 00:24:16.240
or put things together, I really like
this, and it wasn't too difficult.

459
00:24:16.240 --> 00:24:17.960
>> No, it's not, especially.

460
00:24:17.960 --> 00:24:23.470
The great thing about Adobe Premiere is,
I'm just gonna go mess with something.

461
00:24:23.470 --> 00:24:25.150
You can always mess with it and
then go back.

462
00:24:25.150 --> 00:24:26.530
Remember the autosaves?

463
00:24:26.530 --> 00:24:28.180
You can always do that.

464
00:24:28.180 --> 00:24:30.420
What does it do?

465
00:24:30.420 --> 00:24:32.090
Too many times people are really afraid.

466
00:24:32.090 --> 00:24:35.400
They're like I'm gonna do something and
I'm not gonna know what happened.

467
00:24:35.400 --> 00:24:37.340
No, it's like what does this thing do?

468
00:24:37.340 --> 00:24:38.090
Click it up.

469
00:24:38.090 --> 00:24:39.450
It's like, have fun with it.

470
00:24:39.450 --> 00:24:40.540
>> That's right.
>> I mean, that's the best part.

471
00:24:40.540 --> 00:24:42.260
And then you have more
fun with your story.

472
00:24:42.260 --> 00:24:47.390
>> I'm gonna say, if there's a knob, or
a switch, flick it, turn it, do whatever.

473
00:24:47.390 --> 00:24:49.020
>> Why not?
>> See what'll happen,

474
00:24:49.020 --> 00:24:49.760
you never know, right?

475
00:24:49.760 --> 00:24:52.290
>> It's not like messing with
your friend's radio in his car,

476
00:24:52.290 --> 00:24:52.870
>> Yeah, exactly.

477
00:24:52.870 --> 00:24:54.230
>> It's like don't touch the buttons.

478
00:24:54.230 --> 00:24:55.600
No, it's like touch the button.

479
00:24:55.600 --> 00:24:58.930
>> Yeah, everything you see, click it find
out what it does, that's the way to play.

480
00:24:58.930 --> 00:24:59.730
>> Absolutely, absolutely.

481
00:24:59.730 --> 00:25:01.660
>> Well James,
we appreciate you dropping by today,

482
00:25:01.660 --> 00:25:04.553
and showing us how we can do these
overwrites and replacements.

483
00:25:04.553 --> 00:25:07.803
It's some really cool stuff, hopefully
it's going to work out very well for

484
00:25:07.803 --> 00:25:09.560
you in your environment as well.

485
00:25:09.560 --> 00:25:12.035
But, looking at the clock, looks like
we've run out of time for today.

486
00:25:12.035 --> 00:25:13.983
>> [SOUND]
>> Well, not for completely today,

487
00:25:13.983 --> 00:25:15.710
we have more shows we'll shoot today.

488
00:25:15.710 --> 00:25:16.440
How about that?
>> Okay, good.

489
00:25:16.440 --> 00:25:17.250
>> So we'll do more for

490
00:25:17.250 --> 00:25:21.070
you guys out there, we'll give you
a little more of that je ne sais quoi.

491
00:25:21.070 --> 00:25:22.180
>> Little more, little more, okay.

492
00:25:22.180 --> 00:25:24.570
>> All right, we appreciate it,
we thank you guys for watching, but

493
00:25:24.570 --> 00:25:25.360
we are gonna sign off.

494
00:25:25.360 --> 00:25:27.770
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

495
00:25:27.770 --> 00:25:28.570
>> I'm James Biddle.

496
00:25:28.570 --> 00:25:30.514
>> We'll see you next time.

497
00:25:30.514 --> 00:25:39.180
[NOISE]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James describe and demo Storyboard edits and Automate to Sequence. They start by creating a new Sequence and then perform Scaling and Set to Frame. Finally, they look at how to order the Sequence and create a video montage to the beat of an audio track.
episodes.title: Storyboard Edit and Automate to Sequence
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.028 --> 00:00:13.464
All right, greetings everyone.

3
00:00:13.464 --> 00:00:14.957
And welcome to another
exciting episode of ITproTV.

4
00:00:14.957 --> 00:00:17.921
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

5
00:00:17.921 --> 00:00:21.620
And in today's episode, well, we're going
on with more in our Premier Pro series.

6
00:00:21.620 --> 00:00:24.310
Joining us back in the studio
again today to be our muse,

7
00:00:24.310 --> 00:00:27.920
our guiding star in that endeavor,
our good friend, Mr. James Bittle.

8
00:00:27.920 --> 00:00:28.630
Welcome back, James.

9
00:00:28.630 --> 00:00:29.440
We're so glad to have you.

10
00:00:29.440 --> 00:00:30.489
>> Thank you, sir.
I'm a muse now.

11
00:00:31.575 --> 00:00:34.120
>> [LAUGH]
>> Okay, so we've done quite a bit.

12
00:00:34.120 --> 00:00:37.401
We've looked at some overwrites,
we've looked at some replace.

13
00:00:37.401 --> 00:00:39.990
We're gonna step it up a little bit here.

14
00:00:39.990 --> 00:00:43.480
We're gonna really step it up and add
some things, because I know at this point

15
00:00:43.480 --> 00:00:45.912
you've probably been going through this,
you've been practicing.

16
00:00:45.912 --> 00:00:47.190
I'm gonna have positive hopes on that.

17
00:00:47.190 --> 00:00:48.580
You've been practicing,
trying some things,

18
00:00:48.580 --> 00:00:50.910
and you're like I've got questions.

19
00:00:50.910 --> 00:00:52.650
And I think I know what
those questions are, and

20
00:00:52.650 --> 00:00:55.220
I'm gonna answer as many of them as I can.

21
00:00:55.220 --> 00:00:59.050
So, what I'm gonna tackle is two things,
storyboard edits and

22
00:00:59.050 --> 00:01:03.555
something called Automate to Sequence,
which I think you're really gonna like.

23
00:01:03.555 --> 00:01:07.615
So, I'm gonna jump back
into my project here.

24
00:01:07.615 --> 00:01:12.915
And what I'm thinking about doing is
adding a lot of reaction shots up here.

25
00:01:12.915 --> 00:01:16.765
I've got these pictures,
I've got this other video I shot.

26
00:01:16.765 --> 00:01:18.145
Me talking is just kinda boring.

27
00:01:19.285 --> 00:01:23.870
And what I'm thinking is a lot of people
get uncomfortable saying I'm gonna,

28
00:01:23.870 --> 00:01:26.100
do I really have to work on it in this?

29
00:01:26.100 --> 00:01:30.400
Can't I make another sequence,
and work on it there?

30
00:01:30.400 --> 00:01:33.540
Absolutely, you can have
multiple sequences.

31
00:01:33.540 --> 00:01:35.930
And I'm gonna show you a really cool
trick you can do with sequences, too.

32
00:01:35.930 --> 00:01:38.730
So, let me come back over
here to the project window.

33
00:01:38.730 --> 00:01:40.350
And I'm gonna hit the tilda key,
make it real big.

34
00:01:40.350 --> 00:01:43.800
And I've got everything organized.

35
00:01:43.800 --> 00:01:45.220
I've even made a sequences bin.

36
00:01:45.220 --> 00:01:50.280
So, I'm going to create a new one,
but without putting any media in it.

37
00:01:50.280 --> 00:01:54.060
Now, this might be a little bit scary,
okay?

38
00:01:54.060 --> 00:01:59.720
What I'm going to do is I'm gonna come
up to File in the menu bar, all right?

39
00:01:59.720 --> 00:02:01.600
And there's just a New.

40
00:02:01.600 --> 00:02:05.812
Within New, you will find, I can
create a new project, a new sequence.

41
00:02:05.812 --> 00:02:09.450
I'm gonna do this later, where people will
actually work in a different project.

42
00:02:09.450 --> 00:02:12.700
And then they'll say, well,
if I work in a different project,

43
00:02:12.700 --> 00:02:16.450
how do I get a sequence from that
project into another project?

44
00:02:16.450 --> 00:02:20.590
And I'm going to show you
why you love media browser.

45
00:02:20.590 --> 00:02:22.500
But I'm gonna do that later with effects,
okay?

46
00:02:22.500 --> 00:02:25.870
For right now, I'm just gonna
say let's do a new sequence.

47
00:02:25.870 --> 00:02:27.000
And what will happen?

48
00:02:27.000 --> 00:02:27.940
This will happen.

49
00:02:29.050 --> 00:02:32.560
You get a menu of how to
create a new sequence,

50
00:02:32.560 --> 00:02:34.265
how to build it from the ground up.

51
00:02:36.265 --> 00:02:38.545
And you may look at it and
go, scared, done, gone.

52
00:02:38.545 --> 00:02:40.125
>> There's a lot of words on the screen.

53
00:02:40.125 --> 00:02:41.375
>> I know, there's a lot of words,

54
00:02:41.375 --> 00:02:43.765
there's a lot of concepts that
you might not be familiar.

55
00:02:43.765 --> 00:02:46.365
It's like, I just wanna make this,
why do I have to know this?

56
00:02:46.365 --> 00:02:52.267
Well, with Adobe, you can get close,
and everything will be fine, all right?

57
00:02:52.267 --> 00:02:54.197
So let me just sorta jump in here.

58
00:02:54.197 --> 00:02:57.477
And, like I said,
top to bottom, left to right.

59
00:02:57.477 --> 00:02:59.467
You have available presets,

60
00:02:59.467 --> 00:03:03.650
as in they know you might be working
with a certain kind of camera.

61
00:03:03.650 --> 00:03:06.680
So, you can just sort
of target that camera.

62
00:03:06.680 --> 00:03:11.350
Well, I kind of worked with something,
a digital SLR, so I'll just look in there.

63
00:03:11.350 --> 00:03:18.460
And I'll say, okay, I'm working,
what was my last sequence?

64
00:03:18.460 --> 00:03:20.780
I don't remember my last sequence.

65
00:03:20.780 --> 00:03:24.520
So, let me jump out of this real quick,
okay?

66
00:03:24.520 --> 00:03:28.740
And go back and say, wait a minute,
is this 1280 by 720?

67
00:03:28.740 --> 00:03:32.450
I've got a couple of different
tricks to figure that out.

68
00:03:32.450 --> 00:03:37.177
Remember, I could say, by going to the
panel menu in the timeline, I could say,

69
00:03:37.177 --> 00:03:40.540
hey, let's reveal
the sequence in the project.

70
00:03:40.540 --> 00:03:44.945
And then, I can use the preview area,
or I can come up to the top with

71
00:03:44.945 --> 00:03:50.014
the timeline highlighted and say,
hey, sequence, show me the settings.

72
00:03:50.014 --> 00:03:54.890
And I'll come up here and
say a-ha, it is 1280 by 720,

73
00:03:54.890 --> 00:03:58.770
and it's 23.976 Frames per second.

74
00:03:58.770 --> 00:03:59.910
Great.

75
00:03:59.910 --> 00:04:05.100
Now I know if I want my sequences to
match, that's all I need to know.

76
00:04:05.100 --> 00:04:06.970
So I'll come up, I'll go sequence.

77
00:04:06.970 --> 00:04:09.200
I'm sorry, file, no.

78
00:04:09.200 --> 00:04:12.040
I often, it's so funny,
I do that a lot where I go to sequence.

79
00:04:12.040 --> 00:04:13.680
I'm like, I'll get my new sequence there.

80
00:04:13.680 --> 00:04:14.750
Wait a minute.

81
00:04:14.750 --> 00:04:17.040
It's File, it's New, it's Sequence.

82
00:04:17.040 --> 00:04:18.660
Everybody does that at some point.

83
00:04:18.660 --> 00:04:22.410
So, if you do that,
welcome to the Adobe club.

84
00:04:22.410 --> 00:04:24.650
Okay, so here we go.

85
00:04:24.650 --> 00:04:27.330
And I'll say, all right,
it defaults to DV,

86
00:04:27.330 --> 00:04:29.950
because everything sort
of started with DV.

87
00:04:29.950 --> 00:04:32.120
And I'll say no, that's not it.

88
00:04:32.120 --> 00:04:34.660
I'll go to Digital SLR,
cuz that's all camera.

89
00:04:34.660 --> 00:04:36.953
720.
And it's like a-ha,

90
00:04:36.953 --> 00:04:40.940
here is something with 24 P at 23.976.

91
00:04:40.940 --> 00:04:43.980
And I'll say, okay.

92
00:04:43.980 --> 00:04:45.560
It'll have a description.

93
00:04:45.560 --> 00:04:49.276
It's generally for a DSLR,
which is kinda what I shot that on.

94
00:04:49.276 --> 00:04:52.940
At 23.976, it's one square pixel.

95
00:04:52.940 --> 00:04:56.530
Hey, this looks a lot like what I did.

96
00:04:56.530 --> 00:05:00.420
So, I'll say, okay, hey,
I can do this, this isn't so bad.

97
00:05:00.420 --> 00:05:01.540
I'll go to Settings.

98
00:05:01.540 --> 00:05:06.170
And there are things in here like, okay,
the editing mode is DSLR, 1920 by 720,

99
00:05:06.170 --> 00:05:08.540
blah blah blah blah blah blah.

100
00:05:08.540 --> 00:05:10.640
We come down here to something
called video previews,

101
00:05:10.640 --> 00:05:14.430
which we're gonna mess with
later at another time, okay?

102
00:05:14.430 --> 00:05:20.170
But these are like your renders, where you
can actually create renders of effects

103
00:05:20.170 --> 00:05:24.845
that might be lower than
what you're working with.

104
00:05:24.845 --> 00:05:27.800
Why?
Because that will make your render time go

105
00:05:27.800 --> 00:05:29.530
faster, if you need to do that.

106
00:05:29.530 --> 00:05:31.562
Maybe your RAM's not so great.

107
00:05:31.562 --> 00:05:34.260
You've got a great computer, but
you had to kinda compromise on the RAM.

108
00:05:34.260 --> 00:05:38.300
So, you can make your previews smaller,
okay?

109
00:05:38.300 --> 00:05:39.460
You can take them down.

110
00:05:39.460 --> 00:05:41.110
It'll render faster.

111
00:05:41.110 --> 00:05:42.760
And then you say but
what happens when I export?

112
00:05:42.760 --> 00:05:44.400
Well, I'll show you that when we export.

113
00:05:44.400 --> 00:05:45.970
Let's worry about this now.

114
00:05:45.970 --> 00:05:47.830
Okay.
>> Eat what's on your plate, Jim.

115
00:05:47.830 --> 00:05:49.320
>> Yeah, I think so.
But that's what happens.

116
00:05:49.320 --> 00:05:51.995
That's what happens in Adobe until you
start thinking, well, what about this,

117
00:05:51.995 --> 00:05:52.984
what about this will happen?

118
00:05:52.984 --> 00:05:55.434
It's like worry about
what's happening now.

119
00:05:55.434 --> 00:05:58.750
Everything in the future,
you can take care of.

120
00:05:58.750 --> 00:05:59.250
Tracks.

121
00:06:00.500 --> 00:06:02.070
This is where I can say,

122
00:06:02.070 --> 00:06:05.620
I don't think I want three video
tracks in this sequence I'm creating.

123
00:06:05.620 --> 00:06:07.490
I'll just make it one, okay?

124
00:06:07.490 --> 00:06:08.970
I just want one.

125
00:06:08.970 --> 00:06:10.670
And then four audio tracks.

126
00:06:10.670 --> 00:06:12.870
I'm just gonna add some music.

127
00:06:14.180 --> 00:06:18.122
And believe it or not,
since I'm adding music,

128
00:06:18.122 --> 00:06:21.211
I'm going to actually have just one.

129
00:06:22.547 --> 00:06:24.319
And you're gonna say to yourself,
but wait a minute.

130
00:06:24.319 --> 00:06:27.320
The last time we did this,
hit the little delete key, there's a plus,

131
00:06:27.320 --> 00:06:28.130
there's a minus.

132
00:06:28.130 --> 00:06:28.920
Delete.

133
00:06:28.920 --> 00:06:31.240
Say wait a minute,
wait a minute, wait a minute.

134

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James dive into Trimming, Moving, and Removing as edits. They start by demonstrating how to create Sub-clips which is like a form of Trimming. Then they show you how to reorder clips by moving them without creating gaps or overwriting. Finally, they look at trimming; removing unwanted bits of audio/video/both using the Trim Tools to perform Rolling and Ripple edits.
episodes.title: Trimming, Removing and Moving

00:30:15.690 --> 00:30:17.540
If I hold down Ctrl and

532
00:30:17.540 --> 00:30:22.240
then hit t, hey I'm doing that side, now
I'm doing that side, now I'm doing both.

533
00:30:22.240 --> 00:30:25.250
I go through the five stages, so to speak.

534
00:30:25.250 --> 00:30:28.910
If I look at it down here,
it's like hey, that's red.

535
00:30:28.910 --> 00:30:33.900
Control + t, there's a ripple trim on that
side, there's a ripple trim on that side.

536
00:30:33.900 --> 00:30:37.190
Wow, there's an overwrite trim there,
overwrite trim there.

537
00:30:37.190 --> 00:30:38.160
Now we're back to rolling.

538
00:30:38.160 --> 00:30:42.174
I'm just holding down Ctrl and
doing t, like that.

539
00:30:42.174 --> 00:30:46.836
Now, if I do things like
Option + left-arrow,

540
00:30:46.836 --> 00:30:50.880
that's trimming with my keyboard.

541
00:30:50.880 --> 00:30:53.491
If I do the Option + right-arrow and
all that,

542
00:30:53.491 --> 00:30:57.230
if I had Shift + Option,
I'm going five forward.

543
00:30:57.230 --> 00:31:02.490
And I'm doing this all with the keyboard,
and a lot of people really dig that.

544
00:31:02.490 --> 00:31:08.420
So you can dig in there and do the whole,
boom, Ctrl + t goes through all of it.

545
00:31:08.420 --> 00:31:11.290
Have a great time with it, and
sometimes the more you feel

546
00:31:11.290 --> 00:31:14.300
confident in how you control it, the more
you feel confident in doing your story.

547
00:31:14.300 --> 00:31:15.770
>> Wow, Jim, this is great stuff.

548
00:31:15.770 --> 00:31:19.170
I hate to do this, but
we're running out of time,

549
00:31:19.170 --> 00:31:22.160
and I'm just like,
this is great, this is awesome.

550
00:31:22.160 --> 00:31:25.844
I'm gonna go play with this stuff
[LAUGH] as soon as humanly possible,

551
00:31:25.844 --> 00:31:28.576
which I guess is now because
we have to end our show.

552
00:31:28.576 --> 00:31:31.860
But the good news is,
Jim will be back with more shows.

553
00:31:31.860 --> 00:31:34.840
So I'm really looking forward to
seeing what he's got lined up for

554
00:31:34.840 --> 00:31:36.290
us in the upcoming episodes.

555
00:31:36.290 --> 00:31:37.170
Jim, thank you so much.

556
00:31:37.170 --> 00:31:37.950
>> No problem, man.
Glad to be here.

557
00:31:37.950 --> 00:31:39.950
>> For showing us how to use
Premiere a little better than we

558
00:31:39.950 --> 00:31:40.990
probably already know how to do.

559
00:31:40.990 --> 00:31:42.040
>> Nah.
>> With that being said,

560
00:31:42.040 --> 00:31:43.700
we do need to sign off.

561
00:31:43.700 --> 00:31:45.974
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

562
00:31:45.974 --> 00:31:46.886
>> And I'm James.

563
00:31:46.886 --> 00:31:48.967
>> We'll see you next time.

564
00:31:48.967 --> 00:31:57.570
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James discuss speed changes in your sequence(s). They import a sequence from another project and show you how to perform a "Slip" or retime of a clip using the Slip Tool. They also demonstrate speeding up and slowing down using the Stretch tool.
episodes.title: Speed Changes
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.721 --> 00:00:13.698
All right, greetings, everyone, and

3
00:00:13.698 --> 00:00:15.980
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.980 --> 00:00:17.232
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

5
00:00:17.232 --> 00:00:21.712
In this episode, we move forth with
more of our Premier Pro series, and

6
00:00:21.712 --> 00:00:25.522
a voyager that is here to help
us out with that very endeavor,

7
00:00:25.522 --> 00:00:28.230
my good friend, [LAUGH] Mr. James Biddle.

8
00:00:28.230 --> 00:00:29.916
James, welcome back, sir,
we're so glad to have you.

9
00:00:29.916 --> 00:00:31.612
>> Good, it's great to be back everybody.

10
00:00:31.612 --> 00:00:32.802
Hey, last episode,

11
00:00:32.802 --> 00:00:36.980
toward the end there, I got really
nerded out on the whole trimming thing.

12
00:00:36.980 --> 00:00:40.690
Once you really get into Adobe and
you learn a lot of this stuff,

13
00:00:40.690 --> 00:00:42.312
you will do the same thing.

14
00:00:42.312 --> 00:00:45.711
You'll be like watch this, hey,
watch this, watch what I do, okay?

15
00:00:45.711 --> 00:00:49.018
So in this one, I wanna address a few
things that you might have tried some

16
00:00:49.018 --> 00:00:52.370
stuff, and you've run into some
problems and clarify a few things.

17
00:00:52.370 --> 00:00:54.379
But then we're going to
address speed changes.

18
00:00:54.379 --> 00:00:57.120
Everybody loves, let's speed this up,
let's slow this down.

19
00:00:57.120 --> 00:01:01.224
And there's a variety of different
ways to do that in Adobe Premier,

20
00:01:01.224 --> 00:01:05.071
and some speed changes do different
things than others, okay?

21
00:01:05.071 --> 00:01:07.190
So I wanna go back to
my timeline real quick.

22
00:01:07.190 --> 00:01:11.317
Because I bet a lot of you are really,
[LAUGH] I know a lot of people here

23
00:01:11.317 --> 00:01:14.442
have been nerding out about
Automate To Sequence.

24
00:01:14.442 --> 00:01:17.020
And it's like, this is it,
this is gonna save me so much time.

25
00:01:17.020 --> 00:01:21.490
Well, sometimes you might try it, and
you don't get exactly what you want.

26
00:01:21.490 --> 00:01:23.720
Let me give you an example here.

27
00:01:23.720 --> 00:01:29.009
I've set up all these markers, and what
I wanna do is I wanna put in five shots,

28
00:01:29.009 --> 00:01:32.877
one here, one here, one here,
one here, and one here.

29
00:01:32.877 --> 00:01:36.000
And I wanna use that cool
Automate To Sequence thing.

30
00:01:36.000 --> 00:01:39.390
We talked in one of the earlier lessons
about over write, where I said, hey,

31
00:01:39.390 --> 00:01:44.720
you can put your other shots,
your B roll, or your cut away

32
00:01:44.720 --> 00:01:50.708
shots in Video 2 instead of Video 1, and
you may feel more comfortable about that.

33
00:01:50.708 --> 00:01:55.690
Well, let me come back over here to my
project window because I'm gonna use

34
00:01:55.690 --> 00:01:58.290
some of this footage for
something I'm about to do, okay.

35
00:01:58.290 --> 00:02:02.422
And I've selected five items,

36
00:02:02.422 --> 00:02:08.140
and notice nothing is selected so
far as the right side.

37
00:02:08.140 --> 00:02:11.080
If I don't select anything,
nothing will happen.

38
00:02:11.080 --> 00:02:12.970
You know that, okay?

39
00:02:12.970 --> 00:02:16.446
So I'll say, I wanna put that in Video 2,
and it's highlighted.

40
00:02:18.516 --> 00:02:21.964
Come over here, I'm gonna drag
this over to Automate To Sequence,

41
00:02:21.964 --> 00:02:25.540
just plop it on real quick,
you know where that's located.

42
00:02:25.540 --> 00:02:26.660
The dialog's gonna come up.

43
00:02:26.660 --> 00:02:30.170
I'm gonna do it in selection
order cuz I selected everything

44
00:02:30.170 --> 00:02:32.910
in a little bit of a different order.

45
00:02:32.910 --> 00:02:35.610
I'm gonna do it at unnumbered markers,
I'm gonna do the overwrite edit,

46
00:02:35.610 --> 00:02:37.070
you already did that before.

47
00:02:37.070 --> 00:02:39.050
I don't want any audio,
so I'm gonna ignore it.

48
00:02:39.050 --> 00:02:42.900
I'm gonna click OK, and you're gonna say,
hey, that went into Video 2 and

49
00:02:42.900 --> 00:02:46.530
everything was cool, and
I'm gonna be so happy.

50
00:02:46.530 --> 00:02:48.640
Wait a minute, it went into Video 1.

51
00:02:48.640 --> 00:02:51.150
But I had Video 2 chosen.

52
00:02:51.150 --> 00:02:54.020
You'll also notice, there's no sore side.

53
00:02:54.020 --> 00:02:56.420
Since I'm automating it
straight to the sequence,

54
00:02:56.420 --> 00:02:59.170
this is one of the things
that does upset people.

55
00:02:59.170 --> 00:03:03.970
They say, it's just gonna go
into Video 1 every single time.

56
00:03:03.970 --> 00:03:05.820
Yep, that is the default.

57
00:03:05.820 --> 00:03:09.040
So I can do it in another sequence, okay?

58
00:03:09.040 --> 00:03:15.090
I could do it in another sequence, or I
did it in a completely different project.

59
00:03:16.650 --> 00:03:19.390
I did it in a completely different
product, and you'll say, so

60
00:03:19.390 --> 00:03:20.020
what do I have to do?

61
00:03:20.020 --> 00:03:22.470
I have to close the project,
open the project.

62
00:03:22.470 --> 00:03:26.780
Watch this, this is why you will
learn to love Media Browser.

63
00:03:26.780 --> 00:03:30.880
I'm gonna go to the Media Browser
over here, open it up, and

64
00:03:30.880 --> 00:03:33.880
start looking through some stuff, okay?

65
00:03:33.880 --> 00:03:37.100
And okay, I bet I put it in LESSONS,
I did, and

66
00:03:37.100 --> 00:03:41.170
I created a project called Montage.

67
00:03:41.170 --> 00:03:45.620
And when I click on it,
this is what I used in it.

68
00:03:45.620 --> 00:03:49.700
Hey, there's a sequence
there called Montage.

69
00:03:51.440 --> 00:03:55.500
What I'm gonna do is Ctrl+Click and
it's like, wait, so I'm gonna bring it

70
00:03:55.500 --> 00:03:58.160
using Media Browser, I'm looking
a completely different project, and

71
00:03:58.160 --> 00:04:02.110
I'm gonna bring that
sequence into this project.

72
00:04:02.110 --> 00:04:05.330
Yep, just like Menopollusen Voyagers,

73
00:04:05.330 --> 00:04:09.720
gonna hit that stopwatch,
boom, bam, there it is.

74
00:04:09.720 --> 00:04:13.950
And I have a Montage sequence in here.

75
00:04:13.950 --> 00:04:15.620
Now here's the cool thing I can do.

76
00:04:15.620 --> 00:04:16.720
>> Cooler than that?

77
00:04:16.720 --> 00:04:17.312
>> Cooler than that.

78
00:04:17.312 --> 00:04:18.119
>> I can't believe it.

79
00:04:18.119 --> 00:04:21.400
>> A lot of people don't realize
you can do this with sequences.

80
00:04:21.400 --> 00:04:25.038
I'm gonna Ctrl+Click it,
come down here, and

81
00:04:25.038 --> 00:04:29.490
it's gonna say, wait, woah,
woah, are you kidding me?

82
00:04:29.490 --> 00:04:32.720
Where did it go, where did it go,
where did it go, where did it go?

83
00:04:32.720 --> 00:04:34.430
I have an Open in Source Monitor?

84
00:04:35.450 --> 00:04:36.620
Yeah, I do.

85
00:04:36.620 --> 00:04:38.630
I have an Open in Source Monitor.

86
00:04:38.630 --> 00:04:44.864
Boom, this is now in the source monitor,
and I can edit this in,

87
00:04:44.864 --> 00:04:51.675
just like, It's a clip.

88
00:04:51.675 --> 00:04:53.600
And I'll do that, and I'll say overwrite.

89
00:04:54.740 --> 00:04:56.230
Okay, let's overwrite that in.

90
00:04:56.230 --> 00:04:57.160
Is it not overwriting?

91
00:04:57.160 --> 00:04:58.180
You know why?

92
00:04:58.180 --> 00:05:00.140
Cuz it's also just like a clip.

93
00:05:00.140 --> 00:05:01.690
This V2 thing over here doesn't matter.

94
00:05:01.690 --> 00:05:04.970
I have to take the V1 on the right side,
pop it in.

95
00:05:04.970 --> 00:05:06.750
It was disabled, so I got nothing.

96
00:05:07.890 --> 00:05:12.990
Overwrite, boom, and you're like,
whoa, wait a minute, wait a minute.

97
00:05:12.990 --> 00:05:14.249
Why is it a green line?

98
00:05:15.800 --> 00:05:19.182
Well, right now,
it's bringing it in as a nest.

99
00:05:19.182 --> 00:05:23.010
If I double-click this,
it shows me what's inside the nest.

100
00:05:23.010 --> 00:05:25.270
And what's inside the nest
is all the shots.

101
00:05:25.270 --> 00:05:28.090
And I'll say that is inconvenient.

102
00:05:28.090 --> 00:05:29.470
Can I change this?

103
00:05:29.470 --> 00:05:31.180
Yes, it's with this thing.

104
00:05:32.990 --> 00:05:38.730
It'll say, insert and overwrite
sequences as nests or individual clips.

105
00:05:38.730 --> 00:05:43.550
Now this has gotta be a before and
after kind of situation.

106
00:05:43.550 --> 00:05:46.969
I can't already have the nest in,
click this thing, and

107
00:05:46.969 --> 00:05:51.116
then say, now it's not a nest anymore,
I can't do it that way.

108
00:05:53.192 --> 00:05:57.267
If you see this symbol and it is blue,
it looks like the sequence symbol and

109
00:05:57.267 --> 00:05:59.060
it's xed out.

110
00:05:59.060 --> 00:06:01.860
That means, guess what,
it's coming over as a nest,

111
00:06:01.860 --> 00:06:06.680
the individual tracks and
clips have been marked out.

112
00:06:07.750 --> 00:06:12.110
If I click this, then it says look,
there's everything.

113
00:06:12.110 --> 00:06:16.000
It has a Video 3,
the Video 1 moved, great, so

114
00:06:16.000 --> 00:06:19.590
now I can just do this again, okay.

115
00:06:19.590 --> 00:06:23.750
I'll bring this back,
put it under the marker, okay?

116
00:06:23.750 --> 00:06:30.960
And overwrite its period, boom, there it
is, and it comes in as individual clips.

117
00:06:30.960 --> 00:06:34.430
So now I have my individual clips,
and I'm very, very happy.

118
00:06:34.430 --> 00:06:36.440
So that's what this thing does.

119
00:06:36.440 --> 00:06:38.420
If I edit sequences into sequences,

120
00:06:38.420 --> 00:06:42.020
I can do them as nests,
where everything is encapsulated.

121
00:06:42.020 --> 00:06:47.310
Or I can just say, don't do that, and
break it out into its individual clips.

122
00:06:47.310 --> 00:06:50.260
And then I am a very happy person.

123
00:06:50.260 --> 00:06:51.429
>> You are a man of many talents,
my friend.

124
00:06:51.429 --> 00:06:54.230
>> Hey, it's all I've got,
man, it's all I've got.

125
00:06:54.230 --> 00:06:57.760
>> Not only did you show us how to import
a sequence from another project, but

126
00:06:57.760 --> 00:07:01.230
you also successfully referenced
a great 80s television star.

127
00:07:01.230 --> 00:07:02.943
>> Thank you, it was wonderful, wonderful.

128
00:07:02.943 --> 00:07:05.441
I mean, how can you not?

129
00:07:05.441 --> 00:07:08.915
Here's another trick before we
start working with speed, okay,

130
00:07:08.915 --> 00:07:11.000
though a lot of people
don't know about this.

131
00:07:11.000 --> 00:07:12.612
What they'll say is okay, so

132
00:07:12.612 --> 00:07:16.103
you're saying you're putting
like B roll of stuff in Video 2.

133
00:07:16.103 --> 00:07:19.775
And you're putting your interview in Video
1, am I just supposed to take notes or

134
00:07:19.775 --> 00:07:20.370
something?

135
00:07:21.390 --> 00:07:26.100
Believe it or not, you come over here,
and you look at what's called the header.

136
00:07:26.100 --> 00:07:27.500
These are called headers.

137
00:07:27.500 --> 00:07:30.284
And as soon as you make them wider, and

138
00:07:30.284 --> 00:07:34.900
you can see them more,
this says Video 1 for the source patch.

139
00:07:34.900 --> 00:07:37.360
Okay, like we did,
we patched Video 1 into Video 2.

140
00:07:37.360 --> 00:07:41.140
This is for track targeting when we were
doing our things like making cuts and

141
00:07:41.140 --> 00:07:42.510
doing all that.

142
00:07:42.510 --> 00:07:43.210
You say, what's that?

143
00:07:44.220 --> 00:07:45.470
That's the name.

144
00:07:45.470 --> 00:07:46.920
So what I can do is I can come down here,
and

145
00:07:46.920 --> 00:07:49.760
I can Ctrl-Click on the header itself and
say please rename this.

146
00:07:49.760 --> 00:07:53.950
Instead of calling it Video 1,
call it Interview.

147
00:07:53.950 --> 00:07:59.188
Boom, and then I'll Ctrl-Click this one,
say Rename, and

148
00:07:59.188 --> 00:08:05.333
I'm gonna call this Broll Garden, and
then I'll go up to video three and

149
00:08:05.333 --> 00:08:09.983
I'll say later I'm going to
be using that for titles.

150
00:08:09.983 --> 00:08:14.495
All right,
now I've made myself some notes.

151
00:08:14.495 --> 00:08:17.085
And I have absolutely made
myself some notes on this.

152
00:08:17.085 --> 00:08:17.985
And you're like that's awesome.

153
00:08:17.985 --> 00:08:19.235
When are we getting your speed?

154
00:08:19.235 --> 00:08:19.735
Okay.

155
00:08:21.769 --> 00:08:24.005
First of all,
we're gonna come back over here.

156
00:08:24.005 --> 00:08:29.960
I'm gonna do my Shift minus to resize
this, or sort of collapse down little bit.

157
00:08:29.960 --> 00:08:34.790
And I'm going to take a look
at what I have done okay.

158
00:08:34.790 --> 00:08:38.260
That is it, that is terrible
it sort of rectifier itself.

159
00:08:38.260 --> 00:08:39.540
But that is terrible

160
00:08:40.650 --> 00:08:43.800
even though this is technically
a formal trimming I like to call this.

161
00:08:43.800 --> 00:08:45.842
Sort of a speed or a time change.

162
00:08:45.842 --> 00:08:50.070
I'm gonna do something that people
kind of feel uncomfortable with.

163
00:08:50.070 --> 00:08:53.670
It is called a slip.

164
00:08:53.670 --> 00:08:56.505
Basically what I've done is,
that length is great.

165
00:08:56.505 --> 00:09:02.340
But, the area that I've taken
from the clip is wrong.

166
00:09:03.640 --> 00:09:05.735
Okay I need to move it.

167
00:09:05.735 --> 00:09:07.620
So it's in a better part of the shot.

168
00:09:08.820 --> 00:09:14.191
So, I have several methods
by which I can do this.

169
00:09:14.191 --> 00:09:21.140
I can double-click it, and then come
over here and size it down and say okay.

170
00:09:21.140 --> 00:09:24.959
So it has this in point and
out point here.

171
00:09:24.959 --> 00:09:28.109
And technically,
it has all of this footage and

172
00:09:28.109 --> 00:09:31.750
I wish I could just take the length,
but move it there.

173
00:09:33.540 --> 00:09:39.940
If I zoom in on this, it has a little
handle and I can click on it.

174
00:09:39.940 --> 00:09:44.820
Okay and click, come here, this is what
gets me every single, there you go.

175
00:09:44.820 --> 00:09:47.250
Grab it and then move it over.

176
00:09:47.250 --> 00:09:48.860
Let me zoom out quickly.

177
00:09:48.860 --> 00:09:54.870
And it's now showing me where the endpoint
lands and where the out point lands.

178
00:09:56.300 --> 00:09:58.570
And because I double-clicked
it from the sequence.

179
00:09:58.570 --> 00:10:00.720
It's telling me you're working
with the one in the sequence.

180
00:10:00.720 --> 00:10:02.140
So now if I let go, boom.

181
00:10:03.600 --> 00:10:06.290
And that is one way to slip this.

182
00:10:06.290 --> 00:10:07.580
Say okay, I like that better.

183
00:10:08.580 --> 00:10:15.217
I like that better and I sort of,
in a way I have sort of re-timed it.

184
00:10:15.217 --> 00:10:15.845
Okay?

185
00:10:15.845 --> 00:10:17.780
And I like that.

186
00:10:17.780 --> 00:10:20.160
I re-timed it, it looks better.

187
00:10:20.160 --> 00:10:24.000
You don't have to do it that way,
let me re-time another one.

188
00:10:24.000 --> 00:10:25.230
Okay?

189
00:10:25.230 --> 00:10:27.300
And what I'm just doing is I'm
just changing its time location.

190
00:10:28.660 --> 00:10:29.805
Here's this cactus.

191
00:10:29.805 --> 00:10:33.840
Maybe, that's all right, but
I think there's a better part of it, but

192
00:10:33.840 --> 00:10:34.860
I like that distance.

193
00:10:36.290 --> 00:10:38.960
