00:23:52.600 --> 00:23:56.486
So that's how these speed
changes work with this.

433
00:23:56.486 --> 00:24:01.414
The thing is, I can't do audio with this.

434
00:24:01.414 --> 00:24:05.812
When I use this type of Speed,
motion change in the timeline,

435
00:24:05.812 --> 00:24:10.378
I can't do audio, you'd have to
make some cuts in your audio and

436
00:24:10.378 --> 00:24:13.440
kind of fineagle that around a little bit.

437
00:24:13.440 --> 00:24:16.870
If I go in and I do my interview,
and I change this real quick,

438
00:24:16.870 --> 00:24:20.695
it's going to be like okay now
you're video is real fast here but

439
00:24:20.695 --> 00:24:24.135
your audio stays the same length,
now you're out of sync.

440
00:24:24.135 --> 00:24:28.315
And there's no way to correct that,
so be careful when you're doing this.

441
00:24:28.315 --> 00:24:29.155
Have fun with it but

442
00:24:29.155 --> 00:24:32.845
just realize the limitations of all
the things you are working with.

443
00:24:32.845 --> 00:24:37.700
When you make speed changes in
the timeline you're doing a small section.

444
00:24:37.700 --> 00:24:41.700
You're doing a small section and
it's going to effect everything around it.

445
00:24:41.700 --> 00:24:46.290
If I'm doing speed duration or if I'm
doing the rate change tool you can do

446
00:24:46.290 --> 00:24:49.720
audio and
video at the same time keep it in sync.

447
00:24:49.720 --> 00:24:53.360
Things going out of sync really tend
to disturb people it's like I've done

448
00:24:53.360 --> 00:24:54.660
a bad thing.

449
00:24:54.660 --> 00:24:58.380
You'll get used to the fact that you
put stuff out of sync all the time.

450
00:24:58.380 --> 00:24:59.690
I'm gonna do it later.

451
00:24:59.690 --> 00:25:04.010
I'm gonna show you how in one easy step,
you can actually put stuff back into sync.

452
00:25:04.010 --> 00:25:05.750
It's a lot easier than people think it is,

453
00:25:05.750 --> 00:25:07.610
because it's like,
wait you can click that?

454
00:25:07.610 --> 00:25:09.540
Yes you can click that,
and they didn't know.

455
00:25:09.540 --> 00:25:14.130
So that's speed, that is how speed
works in Adobe, and it's really fun.

456
00:25:14.130 --> 00:25:16.000
You can do entire clips.

457
00:25:16.000 --> 00:25:18.670
Or you can do small sections of clips,
just with the key grips.

458
00:25:18.670 --> 00:25:23.150
>> Yeah, and I like how they have multiple
tools for speed for multiple jobs.

459
00:25:23.150 --> 00:25:25.190
>> Exactly.
>> If we were using our last example like

460
00:25:25.190 --> 00:25:28.410
you said, doing it with audio's
not really gonna be that awesome.

461
00:25:28.410 --> 00:25:31.190
Cuz it's gonna freak it out,
it's gonna make it sound weird.

462
00:25:31.190 --> 00:25:33.800
So it's a tool for a specific job.

463
00:25:33.800 --> 00:25:38.100
We have tools for increasing the speed
with audio and video as well.

464
00:25:38.100 --> 00:25:40.860
When you have those things together you
have to know which one to use and when to

465
00:25:40.860 --> 00:25:45.380
use it and you're doing a fantastic
job of demonstrating that for us.

466
00:25:45.380 --> 00:25:46.880
James, we do appreciate it.

467
00:25:46.880 --> 00:25:49.840
>> And I know people get really,
when they see this, they get really upset.

468
00:25:49.840 --> 00:25:52.210
But it left a gap, now what do I do?

469
00:25:52.210 --> 00:25:53.130
That's why we did trimming.

470
00:25:53.130 --> 00:25:56.680
You can trim it over, you can edit it
over, and take care of it that way.

471
00:25:56.680 --> 00:26:00.410
So you've already gone through some
lessons where you now have this arsenal of

472
00:26:00.410 --> 00:26:03.750
things, if that happens it's I could do
this, I could do this, I could do this.

473
00:26:03.750 --> 00:26:04.425
That's not a problem.

474
00:26:04.425 --> 00:26:06.140
>> [LAUGH]
>> And that's what you learn with editors.

475
00:26:06.140 --> 00:26:07.520
We're like therapists.

476
00:26:07.520 --> 00:26:08.760
It's like we'll worry about that later.

477
00:26:08.760 --> 00:26:10.140
Everything's fine, let's just keep going.

478
00:26:10.140 --> 00:26:10.965
>> Let's talk about your mother.

479
00:26:10.965 --> 00:26:12.250
[LAUGH]
>> Let's talk about your mom, and

480
00:26:12.250 --> 00:26:13.520
how she affects your timeline.

481
00:26:13.520 --> 00:26:15.470
Sit down, smoke a cigarette.

482
00:26:15.470 --> 00:26:16.085
So yeah.

483
00:26:16.085 --> 00:26:19.340
So, you're getting,
the more you get used to this,

484
00:26:19.340 --> 00:26:22.810
the more you're gonna feel like, I know
nine different ways to correct that.

485
00:26:22.810 --> 00:26:25.000
Let me just stay in here now,
I'll go back and do that later.

486
00:26:25.000 --> 00:26:25.770
>> Awesome stuff.

487
00:26:25.770 --> 00:26:26.840
Thank you so much James.

488
00:26:26.840 --> 00:26:27.940
>> No problem, man.
>> We appreciate that.

489
00:26:27.940 --> 00:26:30.770
I'm sure you guys are getting
a lot out of this, I know I am.

490
00:26:30.770 --> 00:26:33.920
The problem is, is that for
this episode we have come to a close.

491
00:26:33.920 --> 00:26:34.920
We do appreciate you.

492
00:26:34.920 --> 00:26:36.140
We thank James for stopping by.

493
00:26:36.140 --> 00:26:37.150
We thank you for watching.

494
00:26:37.150 --> 00:26:38.350
And we're going to go ahead and sign off.

495
00:26:38.350 --> 00:26:40.960
For ITPro.TV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

496
00:26:40.960 --> 00:26:41.670
>> I'm James Biddle.

497
00:26:41.670 --> 00:26:43.911
>> And we'll see you next time.

498
00:26:43.911 --> 00:26:52.700
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James explore adding visual effects to your project. Techniques covered include linear keyframe changes (zooming in/out of still images using keyframes), creating effect presets (reusing attributes on multiple stills so you don't have to redo the work), and adding effects to source media to modify all clips.
episodes.title: Visual Effects
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.033 --> 00:00:16.590
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another great episode of ITPro TV.

3
00:00:16.590 --> 00:00:17.760
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie and

4
00:00:17.760 --> 00:00:22.390
in today's episode we continue on with
more of our Adobe Premiere Pro series.

5
00:00:22.390 --> 00:00:24.910
Joining us back in the studio again
today to help us out with that,

6
00:00:24.910 --> 00:00:26.860
is our good friend Mr. James Biddle.

7
00:00:26.860 --> 00:00:28.021
James, welcome back, sir!

8
00:00:28.021 --> 00:00:29.007
>> Hey, what's going on?

9
00:00:29.007 --> 00:00:30.580
>> How's it going?
>> Doing all right, man.

10
00:00:30.580 --> 00:00:31.963
I'm just really excited.

11
00:00:31.963 --> 00:00:34.995
Okay, so
did a lot of stuff in the last lesson.

12
00:00:34.995 --> 00:00:38.895
Now, what everybody's been clamoring for
Visual Effects!

13
00:00:38.895 --> 00:00:40.210
Gaussian blurs!

14
00:00:40.210 --> 00:00:41.258
Tints!

15
00:00:41.258 --> 00:00:41.990
>> Lightsabers.

16
00:00:41.990 --> 00:00:42.741
>> Lightsabers!

17
00:00:42.741 --> 00:00:44.427
>> [LAUGH]
>> No lightsabers.

18
00:00:44.427 --> 00:00:45.090
>> [CROSSTALK] No lightsabers.

19
00:00:45.090 --> 00:00:46.930
>> Okay, but they can get close.

20
00:00:46.930 --> 00:00:50.577
So what I'm gonna start with first, is
I'm gonna start with some motion effects,

21
00:00:50.577 --> 00:00:52.243
how you can do the things with stills or

22
00:00:52.243 --> 00:00:55.030
video to make them move and
do some really cool stuff.

23
00:00:55.030 --> 00:00:58.940
Then we're gonna add some
stuff onto the clips-

24
00:00:58.940 --> 00:01:00.105
>> Like lightsabers?

25
00:01:00.105 --> 00:01:03.090
[LAUGH]
>> I'm a poor student.

26
00:01:03.090 --> 00:01:06.270
>> It's okay, I still value you.

27
00:01:06.270 --> 00:01:09.770
And then I'm gonna show
you how to do something

28
00:01:09.770 --> 00:01:12.430
really cool with Source Clip, okay.

29
00:01:12.430 --> 00:01:13.775
So let's go ahead and get started.

30
00:01:13.775 --> 00:01:15.870
Here's the really cool thing first,
I'm gonna go ahead and

31
00:01:15.870 --> 00:01:21.800
stick to the editing interface,
okay, or the GUI if you will.

32
00:01:21.800 --> 00:01:25.280
And I could switch to the one that's
specifically for Effects, but

33
00:01:25.280 --> 00:01:28.770
I wanna go ahead and stick with
this one for now if you don't mind.

34
00:01:29.910 --> 00:01:34.290
Usually when we want to
see what's on a clip,

35
00:01:34.290 --> 00:01:37.910
in terms of controlling it for
an effect, okay.

36
00:01:37.910 --> 00:01:42.430
When we go up here in the Source area
in general, this is where it's located,

37
00:01:42.430 --> 00:01:47.050
Effects Controls, and
until I highlight a segment

38
00:01:47.050 --> 00:01:51.440
in the timeline, it's empty, all right.

39
00:01:51.440 --> 00:01:56.010
Now what I could do is go through and
click each individual one.

40
00:01:56.010 --> 00:01:59.420
The issue with that is I've
highlighted this one but

41
00:01:59.420 --> 00:02:03.350
my play head's all the way over here and
I'm gonna, all right, let me pull that

42
00:02:03.350 --> 00:02:07.090
over here and then highlight and
it's a real pain in the butt.

43
00:02:07.090 --> 00:02:08.440
But this is what people get used to.

44
00:02:08.440 --> 00:02:10.140
All right.

45
00:02:10.140 --> 00:02:10.930
There's a better way.

46
00:02:12.530 --> 00:02:16.530
And because it deals with
the blue play head and

47
00:02:16.530 --> 00:02:21.110
the blue tracks on the right side, I could
say, hey, in the sequence do me a favor.

48
00:02:22.750 --> 00:02:26.000
Let the selection follow
where the play head goes.

49
00:02:26.000 --> 00:02:28.980
Let me zoom in on this real quick
using the till of the key and

50
00:02:28.980 --> 00:02:33.610
watch this, now every time I go to
a new clip, that one is highlighted.

51
00:02:34.870 --> 00:02:38.090
And now it's gonna show up in the effects
controls and that makes my life so

52
00:02:38.090 --> 00:02:39.000
much better.

53
00:02:39.000 --> 00:02:41.490
What if I want to switch
to what's in video one?

54
00:02:41.490 --> 00:02:44.400
Fine, then I'll just
click video one on and

55
00:02:44.400 --> 00:02:48.310
turn video two off and it's doing those.

56
00:02:48.310 --> 00:02:52.100
And it saves me so much time and headache
to have to go, all right, I'll do this and

57
00:02:52.100 --> 00:02:54.350
then I have to move this back,
that's no fun.

58
00:02:54.350 --> 00:02:55.710
So I'll do that.

59
00:02:55.710 --> 00:02:57.915
I have no idea who that
little voice came from.

60
00:02:57.915 --> 00:02:59.843
>> [LAUGH].
>> So I'm gonna work with this JPEG

61
00:02:59.843 --> 00:03:00.990
right here.

62
00:03:00.990 --> 00:03:06.500
As you can see, what I did was
I brought it into my timeline,

63
00:03:06.500 --> 00:03:09.330
put it in the sequence, and
I said, okay, set to frame size.

64
00:03:09.330 --> 00:03:10.180
I did that.

65
00:03:10.180 --> 00:03:12.850
But I've still got a little bit over here.

66
00:03:12.850 --> 00:03:15.080
Okay, I could still see what's under it.

67
00:03:15.080 --> 00:03:19.290
So, and
because I did set instead of scale,

68
00:03:19.290 --> 00:03:25.740
it's at 18% and I have plenty of
room to make this thing move around.

69
00:03:25.740 --> 00:03:27.590
So, I'm gonna look under
the motion parameters.

70
00:03:27.590 --> 00:03:29.290
What motion parameters do I have?

71
00:03:29.290 --> 00:03:31.740
Well, I'm divided into three areas.

72
00:03:31.740 --> 00:03:36.190
First of all, I have Motion, and
if I click in there, Position,

73
00:03:36.190 --> 00:03:38.450
Scale, Scale Width.

74
00:03:38.450 --> 00:03:43.277
If I choose to separate it,
I'm doing a uniform scale today.

75
00:03:43.277 --> 00:03:49.348
Rotation, Anchor Point and
Anti-flicker Filter.

76
00:03:49.348 --> 00:03:52.518
Opacity, I have my blend modes.

77
00:03:52.518 --> 00:03:56.070
It's like oo,
if I know my Photoshop stuff and

78
00:03:56.070 --> 00:03:59.830
I know my Blend modes,
I can do blending in here.

79
00:03:59.830 --> 00:04:01.490
So I get all of those in here.

80
00:04:01.490 --> 00:04:04.900
So it's not just a normal like turn one
sort of transparent over the other.

81
00:04:04.900 --> 00:04:08.220
I can blend the pixels together one
on top of the other if I want to.

82
00:04:08.220 --> 00:04:09.828
I also have Time Remapping.

83
00:04:09.828 --> 00:04:13.570
So I could've done the Time Remapping
in here, but I will tell you,

84
00:04:13.570 --> 00:04:15.690
that's kind of rough.

85
00:04:15.690 --> 00:04:17.590
That is actually kind of rough.

86
00:04:17.590 --> 00:04:21.570
Notice under Opacity, something that we're
going to do in some of the other effects

87
00:04:21.570 --> 00:04:29.200
later, I have masks that I can now do in
here without having to add another layer.

88
00:04:29.200 --> 00:04:29.980
It's kind of fun though.

89
00:04:29.980 --> 00:04:34.780
We're gonna do that with titles later, but
I can now add a mask to certain effects,

90
00:04:34.780 --> 00:04:38.200
and only affect a certain area,
which is nice.

91
00:04:38.200 --> 00:04:40.767
Especially if you needed
to blur out my face, if you

92
00:04:40.767 --> 00:04:44.408
need to do a Gaussian blur and blur out
my face cuz I was ratting on the mob or

93
00:04:44.408 --> 00:04:48.263
something, I can just put on the Gaussian
blur effect, and then do it here.

94
00:04:48.263 --> 00:04:49.727
Same thing with Opacity.

95
00:04:49.727 --> 00:04:52.918
If I need to make to something kinda
disappear, I could do that as well.

96
00:04:52.918 --> 00:04:58.700
All right, so in motion,
the thing I need to affect is the scale.

97
00:04:58.700 --> 00:05:01.230
So if I wanted to do
just overall to the clip,

98
00:05:01.230 --> 00:05:06.580
doesn't matter, put my little hand on
there and bump it up, and there it is.

99
00:05:06.580 --> 00:05:08.610
That's nice, that's terrific.

100
00:05:08.610 --> 00:05:10.420
It's there and it's a happy thing.

101
00:05:10.420 --> 00:05:11.370
Everything is great.

102
00:05:12.430 --> 00:05:13.900
But now I want to ramp this up.

103
00:05:13.900 --> 00:05:16.190
I want kind of do like
that Ken Burns effect.

104
00:05:16.190 --> 00:05:19.900
Maybe I want to zoom it in and
all that, move it around.

105
00:05:19.900 --> 00:05:20.400
Okay.

106
00:05:21.530 --> 00:05:24.420
So I'm gonna zoom in here.

107
00:05:24.420 --> 00:05:27.160
Whenever I want to do that,
the first thing I have to do is say,

108
00:05:27.160 --> 00:05:29.750
hey, I need to activate some keyframes.

109
00:05:29.750 --> 00:05:31.640
What you want to know about keyframes,

110
00:05:31.640 --> 00:05:34.340
this is something that
has to happen over time.

111
00:05:34.340 --> 00:05:38.380
When I just kicked this up to 22%,
it just did the whole thing.

112
00:05:38.380 --> 00:05:41.660
When I activate keyframes, it's like I
want to do something that happens at this

113
00:05:41.660 --> 00:05:46.580
moment and then interpolate,
as we say, to another moment.

114
00:05:46.580 --> 00:05:49.280
That's why I click on the stopwatch.

115
00:05:49.280 --> 00:05:53.870
And it's like, okay, I have toggled
the animation, I get some new things here.

116
00:05:53.870 --> 00:05:58.110
It says, hey, here's this new thing,
it's like, you've added one keyframe.

117
00:05:58.110 --> 00:05:59.610
It's right there.

118
00:05:59.610 --> 00:06:03.010
I can now add and
move keyframes with this button.

119
00:06:03.010 --> 00:06:07.510
I can also go directly to other
keyframes with these buttons.

120
00:06:07.510 --> 00:06:09.740
These become very helpful later.

121
00:06:09.740 --> 00:06:11.940
It's like,
how do I know I'm right on that keyframe?

122
00:06:11.940 --> 00:06:13.840
Use the buttons.

123
00:06:13.840 --> 00:06:16.960
Gonna go forward a little bit and
I'm gonna say, okay,

124
00:06:16.960 --> 00:06:23.060
this is gonna be my animation point and I
can either drop another keyframe, this is

125
00:06:23.060 --> 00:06:25.760
one of the things, do I drop the keyframe
first or do I change the parameter?

126
00:06:27.000 --> 00:06:29.130
It all depends on what you
feel most comfortable with.

127
00:06:29.130 --> 00:06:31.020
Some people say,
I always drop the keyframe and

128
00:06:31.020 --> 00:06:34.360
then change the parameter, everybody
tells that, I just put in them big thing.

129
00:06:35.470 --> 00:06:39.676
What I'm gonna do is go ahead and
drop the keyframe and then say,

130
00:06:39.676 --> 00:06:45.840
all right, let me raise that up,
that goes really fast.

131
00:06:45.840 --> 00:06:48.620
Bring it down and
say I wanna raise it up to about, there.

132
00:06:50.390 --> 00:06:54.159
If I use this and
go back to the previous keyframe,

133
00:06:54.159 --> 00:06:58.720
it'll take me back there and
then I'm just gonna hit Play.

134
00:06:58.720 --> 00:07:04.840
And it goes up really fast, and
it's like, okay, that was really cool.

135
00:07:05.980 --> 00:07:06.930
It went really fast.

136
00:07:06.930 --> 00:07:11.160
Then I'll say, you know what,
maybe I wanted to extend it a little more.

137
00:07:11.160 --> 00:07:13.640
Doesn't mean I have to erase the keyframe.

138
00:07:13.640 --> 00:07:15.710
I'm gonna say, you know what?

139
00:07:15.710 --> 00:07:18.240
Kind of wish clicking it I'd
have been more down here.

140
00:07:18.240 --> 00:07:21.104
So I can pick them up and move them,
say it should've been faster,

141
00:07:21.104 --> 00:07:22.960
now I'll make it slower.

142
00:07:22.960 --> 00:07:26.950
So now it happens a little bit slower,
like that.

143
00:07:28.550 --> 00:07:32.586
This is a linear keyframe change as in,

144
00:07:32.586 --> 00:07:35.030
if I now come over here,
what does this thing do?

145
00:07:35.030 --> 00:07:36.860
What does this exposure triangle do?

146
00:07:36.860 --> 00:07:37.570
Boom.

147
00:07:37.570 --> 00:07:40.690
It shows me the interpolation,
and it is a linear change.

148
00:07:40.690 --> 00:07:41.320
Just like a ramp.

149
00:07:42.670 --> 00:07:45.809
Doesn't necessarily look
really very natural.

150
00:07:45.809 --> 00:07:49.007
So we're gonna worry about that later.

151
00:07:49.007 --> 00:07:54.395
The thing I'm gonna worry about now is,
okay When I come to this keyframe,

152
00:07:54.395 --> 00:07:57.487
that framing is really kinda silly pants.

153
00:07:57.487 --> 00:08:00.850
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I've gotta do another parameter,

154
00:08:00.850 --> 00:08:02.550
which is the position.

155
00:08:04.010 --> 00:08:07.361
Toggle the animation,
the position of the beginning is fine.

156
00:08:07.361 --> 00:08:08.890
And this is one of my little tricks.

157
00:08:08.890 --> 00:08:10.690
I'm sure other people do it too.

158
00:08:10.690 --> 00:08:15.090
I will, I know that there's
a key frame right here in scale.

159
00:08:15.090 --> 00:08:18.860
So, I'll jump forward to that,
come back to the scale parameter, or

160
00:08:18.860 --> 00:08:20.800
the position parameter.

161
00:08:20.800 --> 00:08:24.350
I'll go ahead, in this case,
just start in changing the position.

162

00:20:54.170 --> 00:20:55.210
Why not?

397
00:20:55.210 --> 00:20:58.545
I can take the Gaussian blur,
command click the tint.

398
00:20:58.545 --> 00:21:04.060
>> Ctrl+click that and save that as
a preset of the blur and the tint.

399
00:21:04.060 --> 00:21:08.450
If I had a motion parameter on it,
I could do the motion, the gauge and

400
00:21:08.450 --> 00:21:12.060
blur, and the tint, and
save that as an entire preset.

401
00:21:13.250 --> 00:21:14.730
Okay, I could save that.

402
00:21:14.730 --> 00:21:18.650
Whole entire thing and
put it on things in the future.

403
00:21:18.650 --> 00:21:21.130
Future projects, timelines, whatever.

404
00:21:21.130 --> 00:21:26.370
So I have that ability to put
multiple effects together and

405
00:21:26.370 --> 00:21:27.340
with a motion parameter.

406
00:21:27.340 --> 00:21:28.030
>> That's really cool then.

407
00:21:28.030 --> 00:21:31.790
Once you create an effect you really
like and obviously as a storyteller and

408
00:21:31.790 --> 00:21:35.070
someone that's editing your own work,
you're gonna come up with a style

409
00:21:35.070 --> 00:21:37.650
of things that you like and now you
can re-use them over and over again.

410
00:21:37.650 --> 00:21:39.350
You don't have to re-invent the wheel.

411
00:21:39.350 --> 00:21:42.540
You just grab your predecessors
you created and apply the effect.

412
00:21:42.540 --> 00:21:45.790
>> Exactly, now here's the one.

413
00:21:45.790 --> 00:21:48.110
Here's the one that everybody's like,
once I show them this,

414
00:21:48.110 --> 00:21:53.210
they're like all right, so
two sides to every story.

415
00:21:53.210 --> 00:21:54.490
Two sides to every segment.

416
00:21:54.490 --> 00:21:55.370
Watch this.

417
00:21:55.370 --> 00:21:59.620
I'm going to turn off the eyeball in V2 so
I can't see what's above it.

418
00:21:59.620 --> 00:22:03.830
I can still work on it,
but I still can't see it.

419
00:22:03.830 --> 00:22:06.340
Video 1,
I'm going to come down to this, of me.

420
00:22:06.340 --> 00:22:07.600
And let's face it.

421
00:22:07.600 --> 00:22:10.500
I shot it so it was too bright.

422
00:22:10.500 --> 00:22:12.080
I shot it so it was too bright.

423
00:22:12.080 --> 00:22:15.360
Was I did was I cut up this clip and
put it in the timeline.

424
00:22:16.810 --> 00:22:22.910
So, Right now it is saying okay.

425
00:22:22.910 --> 00:22:26.430
You have highlighted
this in the sequence and

426
00:22:26.430 --> 00:22:30.230
you are looking at the segment
that you'd use in the sequence.

427
00:22:32.220 --> 00:22:33.260
That's why it's blue.

428
00:22:35.240 --> 00:22:38.070
What is this off to the left?

429
00:22:38.070 --> 00:22:40.150
Wait, left side.

430
00:22:40.150 --> 00:22:41.280
Right side.

431
00:22:41.280 --> 00:22:45.660
If I click this, it is saying,

432
00:22:45.660 --> 00:22:50.250
all right, you would like to
affect the source clip now.

433
00:22:51.370 --> 00:22:52.680
It's like, yes, I would.

434
00:22:52.680 --> 00:22:55.660
It's like,
what would you like to do to it?

435
00:22:55.660 --> 00:23:00.820
I will say, I'm just going to
do a brightness and contrast.

436
00:23:00.820 --> 00:23:02.070
Down here.

437
00:23:02.070 --> 00:23:04.920
And what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna
find it down here in color correction.

438
00:23:04.920 --> 00:23:07.820
I'm gonna click on it and drag it up.

439
00:23:07.820 --> 00:23:09.400
And it has a little plus sign, boom.

440
00:23:09.400 --> 00:23:16.660
And I'm gonna say, all right,
let's do the brightness, yeah, way up.

441
00:23:16.660 --> 00:23:17.870
That's good.
>> That looks nice.

442
00:23:17.870 --> 00:23:18.650
>> That's even better.

443
00:23:18.650 --> 00:23:19.720
>> I like that.

444
00:23:19.720 --> 00:23:20.880
>> I love that.

445
00:23:20.880 --> 00:23:25.870
Do that, adjust some of the contrasts,
and there you go.

446
00:23:25.870 --> 00:23:27.360
I like that a little bit better.

447
00:23:28.550 --> 00:23:32.640
Now the interesting part is because
I placed this on the source clip,

448
00:23:34.360 --> 00:23:39.930
it has done every single one in here.

449
00:23:39.930 --> 00:23:42.560
I didn't have to do them individually, and

450
00:23:42.560 --> 00:23:46.198
because this was cut from
the source clip they're all done.

451
00:23:46.198 --> 00:23:49.741
>> You actually answered a question I was
gonna ask you which is why are we doing it

452
00:23:49.741 --> 00:23:52.450
to the source and not to-
>> Right So it's, wait a minute,

453
00:23:52.450 --> 00:23:54.407
I've used that source multiple times.

454
00:23:54.407 --> 00:24:00.850
If I put an effect on it,
it'll go in there every single time.

455
00:24:00.850 --> 00:24:02.940
I could add an individual effect to this.

456
00:24:02.940 --> 00:24:05.680
I simply go back here and say what?

457
00:24:05.680 --> 00:24:07.610
Well, I, well, let's go to my good friend.

458
00:24:07.610 --> 00:24:10.107
I'll just type in G-A-U-S.

459
00:24:10.107 --> 00:24:10.814
Gasu?

460
00:24:10.814 --> 00:24:12.495
No, G-A-U-S.

461
00:24:12.495 --> 00:24:15.790
Gaussian blur, Gaussian blur,
Gaussian blur, there you are.

462
00:24:15.790 --> 00:24:18.810
Boom, drop it just on the segment.

463
00:24:18.810 --> 00:24:20.110
You drop that in the timeline.

464
00:24:20.110 --> 00:24:22.160
Kick up the blurriness on that.

465
00:24:22.160 --> 00:24:25.790
If I come back down here,
this is the only one that has it.

466
00:24:25.790 --> 00:24:30.260
All the rest of them have the effect
that I put on the source clip.

467
00:24:30.260 --> 00:24:33.110
Could I do this before I
put it into the timeline?

468
00:24:33.110 --> 00:24:33.700
Absolutely.

469
00:24:33.700 --> 00:24:35.710
I could have loaded something
in the source clip and

470
00:24:35.710 --> 00:24:37.540
drug it up to the source clip.

471
00:24:37.540 --> 00:24:42.010
But in this case, since I know I used
this multiple times, there we go.

472
00:24:42.010 --> 00:24:44.240
So, the blurriness is
the only thing I used here.

473
00:24:45.660 --> 00:24:50.190
So that's why some people
will say wait a minute.

474
00:24:50.190 --> 00:24:53.150
But there's clearly
something on all of these,

475
00:24:53.150 --> 00:24:54.690
that's why you have this other side.

476
00:24:56.120 --> 00:24:58.310
That's why you can say, wait a minute,
there's an effect here.

477
00:24:58.310 --> 00:24:59.960
Is it on the source clip?

478
00:24:59.960 --> 00:25:00.750
Yes it is.

479
00:25:01.900 --> 00:25:02.565
And that way I can say,

480
00:25:02.565 --> 00:25:07.070
okay, let me get rid of that Gaussian
blur on here, just the segment itself.

481
00:25:08.520 --> 00:25:10.160
And there you are.

482
00:25:10.160 --> 00:25:15.260
So you can affect individual
segments within the actual sequence.

483
00:25:15.260 --> 00:25:18.190
And you can, in fact, source clips.

484
00:25:18.190 --> 00:25:20.330
And yes, see?

485
00:25:20.330 --> 00:25:21.010
I did this.

486
00:25:21.010 --> 00:25:24.420
Look it, boom, brightness and
contrast, control click.

487
00:25:24.420 --> 00:25:26.110
I can save that preset.

488
00:25:26.110 --> 00:25:30.730
Just because it is in a source clip
doesn't mean I can't save the preset.

489
00:25:30.730 --> 00:25:34.620
I can save it as a preset
once I have adjusted it.

490
00:25:34.620 --> 00:25:37.900
That is absolutely not a problem.

491
00:25:37.900 --> 00:25:41.380
One thing I do want to address
real quick before we go,

492
00:25:42.550 --> 00:25:44.960
I was adjusting each individual parameter.

493
00:25:46.300 --> 00:25:51.130
Some people say I use other applications,
and they have a wire frame, and I miss it.

494
00:25:52.340 --> 00:25:53.350
Doesn't this have it?

495
00:25:54.910 --> 00:25:56.710
And I'll say wait, what's that?

496
00:25:56.710 --> 00:25:59.240
Well, of course, we have fx,
if we turn it off and

497
00:25:59.240 --> 00:26:02.026
on, that turns the effect on and off,
so you can see it with or without.

498
00:26:02.026 --> 00:26:04.260
I am going to come over here,

499
00:26:04.260 --> 00:26:08.380
we address this whole why would I
want to not fit this to window?

500
00:26:08.380 --> 00:26:11.010
Well, sometimes I want to zoom in,
sometimes I want to zoom back.

501
00:26:12.100 --> 00:26:12.600
Why?

502
00:26:13.820 --> 00:26:20.230
Because if I just highlight motion,
there's my wireframe.

503
00:26:20.230 --> 00:26:24.530
And people are like I love the wireframe,
because then I can do the scale this way.

504
00:26:24.530 --> 00:26:26.380
And I can do the rotation this way.

505
00:26:27.510 --> 00:26:29.680
Really?
And then I can move it.

506
00:26:29.680 --> 00:26:30.690
You are the best.

507
00:26:30.690 --> 00:26:31.630
So yes.

508
00:26:31.630 --> 00:26:34.560
I can do that, and
just crank the homeless printer.

509
00:26:34.560 --> 00:26:37.400
Some people absolutely love the wireframe.

510
00:26:38.470 --> 00:26:43.060
And all you have to do is click
on the actual motion itself, and

511
00:26:43.060 --> 00:26:43.890
you get the wireframe.

512
00:26:43.890 --> 00:26:45.800
That's what this little symbol means.

513
00:26:45.800 --> 00:26:48.940
It's like, click on me,
and you get the wireframe.

514
00:26:48.940 --> 00:26:51.349
If you go to the individual parameters,
I go away.

515
00:26:53.160 --> 00:26:56.620
That sometimes answers the mysterious
question of is there a wireframe?

516
00:26:56.620 --> 00:26:57.720
Is there not a wireframe?

517
00:26:57.720 --> 00:27:00.190
Just remember when you do this,
you have to set it back to fit, or

518
00:27:00.190 --> 00:27:02.180
you're like wait, it scaled up too much.

519
00:27:02.180 --> 00:27:04.590
No, you adjusted the fit.

520
00:27:04.590 --> 00:27:07.800
So I hope that encourages people
to really go in there and

521
00:27:07.800 --> 00:27:10.540
do something crazy stuff with effects.

522
00:27:10.540 --> 00:27:13.430
And now you know how to control
the My Key Frames, you know how to stack,

523
00:27:13.430 --> 00:27:17.280
add more, it's like I'm going to put
a bunch on there, and then save it,

524
00:27:17.280 --> 00:27:22.090
do it as a preset, keyframes are nothing,
I just want to go from here to here, and

525
00:27:22.090 --> 00:27:23.510
does what it does.

526
00:27:23.510 --> 00:27:26.900
Here's one last cool thing that
a lot of people ask me about

527
00:27:26.900 --> 00:27:31.870
is what if I want to do that
thing where I zoom in real quick?

528
00:27:31.870 --> 00:27:36.960
And it's, yes, I know what you mean, okay?

529
00:27:36.960 --> 00:27:38.610
I know exactly what you mean.

530
00:27:38.610 --> 00:27:39.800
First of all, I'm going to go back to Set.

531
00:27:39.800 --> 00:27:41.970
I think I blew out everything.

532
00:27:41.970 --> 00:27:43.480
So I believe I have to set the frame size.

533
00:27:43.480 --> 00:27:46.374
Yep, what if I want to do something?

534
00:27:46.374 --> 00:27:47.740
Yeah, I loved 24.

535
00:27:47.740 --> 00:27:54.440
And people will say, hey, do I have to
make a cut and then zoom one or the other?

536
00:27:54.440 --> 00:27:55.870
Try it with keyframes.

537
00:27:55.870 --> 00:27:56.840
This is a lot of fun.

538
00:27:56.840 --> 00:27:58.570
We did a thing where we zoomed in.

539
00:27:58.570 --> 00:27:59.159
Watch this.

540
00:28:00.200 --> 00:28:03.710
I will do a scale parameter on this one,
okay?

541
00:28:03.710 --> 00:28:07.650
I'm going to come here and
I will activate scale.

542
00:28:09.090 --> 00:28:10.010
There's one at the beginning.

543
00:28:10.010 --> 00:28:13.250
And then here, all right?

544
00:28:13.250 --> 00:28:17.230
I will kick the scale up to,
I'll just say there,

545
00:28:17.230 --> 00:28:19.530
not going to mess with position right now.

546
00:28:19.530 --> 00:28:20.510
And it's It's linear.

547
00:28:20.510 --> 00:28:22.180
Again, it defaults to linear.

548
00:28:23.400 --> 00:28:25.380
So, I'll zoom in and I'll say okay.

549
00:28:25.380 --> 00:28:30.306
We're going to control click
on the first key frame, and

550
00:28:30.306 --> 00:28:36.490
say hold, and that's going to
hold its value on the first one.

551
00:28:36.490 --> 00:28:40.060
Okay.
And then this second one

552
00:28:40.060 --> 00:28:42.190
should follow suit.

553
00:28:42.190 --> 00:28:43.910
So now, it should look like this.

554
00:28:43.910 --> 00:28:46.980
Hi, I'm Jim Middle, and
I'm currently training you right now.

555
00:28:46.980 --> 00:28:50.360
So now, you get that effect where it's
like you don't have to cut anything.

556
00:28:50.360 --> 00:28:53.320
You just do key frames, and you zoom in,
zoom out, zoom back, and all that.

557
00:28:53.320 --> 00:28:57.730
It's kind of virtual camera-ish,
all right?

558
00:28:57.730 --> 00:28:59.740
So that way it's, we only had one camera.

559
00:28:59.740 --> 00:29:02.490
How do we make it look like we had two?

560
00:29:02.490 --> 00:29:07.010
Well, then I could also take the position
and I could move it over slightly.

561
00:29:07.010 --> 00:29:09.450
I could make the wider shot look centered,
and

562
00:29:09.450 --> 00:29:12.480
make the other one look
slightly to the right or left.

563
00:29:13.930 --> 00:29:16.750
And then I can save the preset and
just pop it on other things and

564
00:29:16.750 --> 00:29:18.500
save myself a bunch of time.

565
00:29:18.500 --> 00:29:21.500
So think about this, you work smarter.

566
00:29:21.500 --> 00:29:25.130
You learn just a few things,
you work smarter, and it's this and that,

567
00:29:25.130 --> 00:29:29.243
I'll just do this,
especially if it's just do this, do that.

568
00:29:29.243 --> 00:29:31.170
>> [LAUGH]
>> So there you go, really cool.

569
00:29:31.170 --> 00:29:33.530
No lightsabers, sorry.

570
00:29:33.530 --> 00:29:37.250
No lightsaber, but
I think this is pretty cool.

571
00:29:37.250 --> 00:29:38.380
I mean, I did reference 24.

572
00:29:38.380 --> 00:29:39.190
>> You did.

573
00:29:39.190 --> 00:29:42.130
>> So I mean,
a little Jack Bauer action there.

574
00:29:42.130 --> 00:29:45.050
>> Yeah, you might not tell us
how to do lightsaber action.

575
00:29:45.050 --> 00:29:49.090
But you did teach us how to make
our stuff look professional,

576
00:29:49.090 --> 00:29:51.130
and that is probably more important.

577
00:29:51.130 --> 00:29:52.656
I know light sabers are fun, but-
>> I need to go to

578
00:29:52.656 --> 00:29:53.720
the lightsaber dark side.

579
00:29:53.720 --> 00:29:54.618
>> Yeah, that's right.

580
00:29:54.618 --> 00:29:56.510
[LAUGH]
>> I'm so sorry.

581
00:29:56.510 --> 00:29:57.070
Cool.

582
00:29:57.070 --> 00:30:01.460
So that is visual effects in a nut shell,
and you can get in there and

583
00:30:01.460 --> 00:30:04.350
play around with them, blend them out,
see how they work, and

584
00:30:04.350 --> 00:30:08.630
have a great, just have a great,
good fun time with visual effects.

585
00:30:08.630 --> 00:30:09.290
>> Awesome stuff, Jim.

586
00:30:09.290 --> 00:30:12.530
We appreciate you showing us how
to work with these effects and

587
00:30:12.530 --> 00:30:14.890
all the awesome demonstrations
as you showed as well.

588
00:30:14.890 --> 00:30:15.830
>> Well, thank you friend.

589
00:30:15.830 --> 00:30:16.810
>> Yeah, well, that being said,

590
00:30:16.810 --> 00:30:18.420
it looks like we've come to
the end of another episode.

591
00:30:18.420 --> 00:30:20.730
Hopefully you guys have enjoyed it,
hope you learned a little bit.

592
00:30:20.730 --> 00:30:21.900
We're going to go ahead and sign off.

593
00:30:21.900 --> 00:30:24.670
For ITProTV, I've been your host,
Daniel Laurie.

594
00:30:24.670 --> 00:30:25.290
>> I'm James Middle.

595
00:30:25.290 --> 00:30:27.196
>> We'll see you next time.

596
00:30:27.196 --> 00:30:36.350
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James demonstrate implementing Transitions. They will show you how to add transitions like dissolves, wipes, 3d boxes and manipulate their affect/attributes more/less longer/shorter. Then they look at using Sync Lock and Clip Handles.
episodes.title: Transitions
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.170 --> 00:00:16.720
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:16.720 --> 00:00:17.820
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

4
00:00:17.820 --> 00:00:22.600
In today's episode, we continue on
with our Adobe Premier Pro series.

5
00:00:22.600 --> 00:00:27.390
Joining us back in the studio is the
Premier Pro master himself, that's right,

6
00:00:27.390 --> 00:00:28.150
Mr. James Biddle.

7
00:00:28.150 --> 00:00:28.739
James, Welcome back.

8
00:00:28.739 --> 00:00:31.001
>> No pressure there,
I'm gonna make mistakes, yes I do.

9
00:00:31.001 --> 00:00:32.840
>> You are gonna crash
hard in this episode.

10
00:00:32.840 --> 00:00:33.537
>> As soon as you, yeah.

11
00:00:33.537 --> 00:00:34.720
>> [LAUGH]
>> Just boom.

12
00:00:34.720 --> 00:00:38.010
>> As soon as you start making mistakes
in Adobe, you have joined the club.

13
00:00:38.010 --> 00:00:40.062
If you claim you've never made a mistake,
go away.

14
00:00:40.062 --> 00:00:41.290
>> [LAUGH]
>> I mean it's like I

15
00:00:41.290 --> 00:00:42.300
make mistakes all the time.

16
00:00:42.300 --> 00:00:47.150
All right, so transitions now,
wow, dissolved 3D cube spins,

17
00:00:47.150 --> 00:00:48.300
that kind of stuff.

18
00:00:48.300 --> 00:00:48.970
How do we do that?

19
00:00:48.970 --> 00:00:52.160
Can I add multiple
transitions at the same time?

20
00:00:52.160 --> 00:00:52.690
Absolutely.

21
00:00:52.690 --> 00:00:56.060
We're gonna explore it and it's not
a very long lesson, but I will try and

22
00:00:56.060 --> 00:00:59.150
get as dense as possible as the things
that you can do with transitions and

23
00:00:59.150 --> 00:01:00.850
make your life a little bit easier.

24
00:01:00.850 --> 00:01:03.030
So we're going back to the old interface.

25
00:01:03.030 --> 00:01:05.650
I love it, it makes me feel so good.

26
00:01:05.650 --> 00:01:06.330
Okay.

27
00:01:06.330 --> 00:01:08.370
Couple things I wanna address.

28
00:01:08.370 --> 00:01:09.090
Here's something neat.

29
00:01:11.325 --> 00:01:13.590
If I go back up to the top here,
what's that mean?

30
00:01:13.590 --> 00:01:14.920
What's the little asterisk mean?

31
00:01:14.920 --> 00:01:20.490
I bet if I come over here and
go save, I bet it goes away.

32
00:01:20.490 --> 00:01:25.030
If you have an asterisk up in this
line right here, right at the end,

33
00:01:25.030 --> 00:01:28.810
it's kind of like warning you,
you haven't saved in a while..

34
00:01:28.810 --> 00:01:30.873
And if things go [SOUND] you may lose it,

35
00:01:30.873 --> 00:01:34.432
especially if you don't have your
auto-save set a certain way.

36

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James take a closer look at adjusting audio in Premiere. They begin by synchronizing audio tracks and how to use both clip and track keyframes. They also discuss track mixing and adding music using the Timeline as well as the Track Mixer. Finally, they demonstrate how to create a sub-mix.
episodes.title: Audio Adjustments

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James show you how to add effects to your audio tracks. They get started by working with track and clip keyframes, as well as the sub-frame view for fine tuning. Then they show the steps necessary to add effects like reverb, from the built-in effect plugins. Also discussed is the Loudness Radar tool and audio hardware compatibility and use.
episodes.title: Audio Effects

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James show you how to add titles to your work by employing the Title Tool, aka The Titler. With the title tool, not only can you add titles but you can also add effects to your titles, which they show. They also show you how to work with the Typekit from the Adobe Create Cloud and explain the Title and Action Safe Area to keep your titles from getting clipped.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James dive into performing color correction in Premiere. They start off by showing you how to set the black, white, and grey levels. Then they show you the 3-way Color Corrector and Luma tools. They demonstrate working with shadows, midtones, and highlights and the Color Window.
episodes.title: Color Corrections

00:26:46.560 --> 00:26:51.540
The difference between that is if you

00:26:51.540 --> 00:26:56.630

you are not effecting the overall luma.

00:26:56.630 --> 00:26:58.940

Now I know some people who are really,
really into color correction,

00:27:04.865 --> 00:27:06.631
I'm basically just
talking about the color.

00:27:06.631 --> 00:27:11.870
So you're effecting the color
separately from the luma.

00:27:11.870 --> 00:27:18.490
If I'm using curves, it's on a film basis,
like red, green, blue make white.

466
00:27:19.520 --> 00:27:23.550
And they make luma, so
sometimes when you affect the red, green,

467
00:27:23.550 --> 00:27:25.690
blue, you're affecting the overall luma.

468
00:27:26.690 --> 00:27:30.069
Practice that as much as possible,

469
00:27:31.760 --> 00:27:36.180
Usually your dials or
your hue saturation curves

00:27:36.180 --> 00:27:39.830
are based on a television signal with
a luma or chroma were sent separately.

00:27:40.855 --> 00:27:44.549

owned black and white televisions.

00:27:44.549 --> 00:27:49.511
If they were sending a color signal, still
had to be able to see it, so that's why.

473
00:27:49.511 --> 00:27:51.630
Film, film is film.

00:27:51.630 --> 00:27:54.200

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and James explain the processes of saving, exporting, and sharing your Premiere Pro projects. They begin by uploading your project settings to the Adobe Creative Cloud for use on later projects. Then they show you how to export your settings locally. Next, they demonstrate sharing your projects, whether in piece or in full. Lastly, they look at Edit Decision Lists(EDL), OMF for audio, Marker Lists, and a step-by-step export of media.
episodes.title: Saving, Exporting and Sharing
